openai_summarised_points: • The United States has a highly developed mixed economy, ranking as the world's largest economy by nominal GDP and the second largest by purchasing power parity (PPP) as of 2025.
• In 2025, the U.S. holds the seventh highest nominal GDP per capita and the ninth highest GDP per capita by PPP globally.
• The U.S. accounts for 27% of the global economy in nominal terms and about 16% in PPP terms in 2025.

• The U.S. dollar serves as the most widely used currency of record in international transactions and is the world’s primary reserve currency, supported by a large U.S. Treasuries market, its role as the reference standard for the petrodollar system, and its linked eurodollar.
• Several countries officially use the U.S. dollar as their currency, while in others it functions as the de facto currency.
• Since the end of World War II, the U.S. economy has experienced relatively steady growth, low unemployment and inflation, and rapid technological advancements.
• The American economy is driven by high productivity, a well-developed transportation infrastructure, and abundant natural resources.
• Americans have the sixth highest average household and employee income among OECD member states.
• In 2021, the U.S. had the highest median household income among OECD countries but also exhibited one of the highest income inequalities among developed nations.
• The largest U.S. trading partners include Canada, Mexico, China, Japan, Germany, South Korea, the United Kingdom, Taiwan, India, and Vietnam.
• The U.S. is the world’s largest importer and the second-largest exporter of goods and services.

• The U.S. maintains free trade agreements with several countries, notably Canada and Mexico through the USMCA, as well as Australia, South Korea, Israel, among others, with some agreements under negotiation.
• The U.S. labor market is highly flexible, characterized by a hire-and-fire policy and relatively low job security.
• Among OECD nations, the U.S. has a highly efficient social security system, with social expenditure amounting to roughly 30% of GDP.
• The United States is the world’s largest producer of petroleum, natural gas, and blood products.
• In 2016, the U.S. was the world’s largest trading country and the second-largest manufacturer, with American manufacturing constituting one-fifth of the global total.
• The U.S. possesses the largest internal market for goods and dominates the global services trade.
• Total U.S. trade volume reached $4.2 trillion in 2018.
• Of the world’s 500 largest companies, 139 are headquartered in the United States.
• The U.S. has the highest number of billionaires worldwide, with a combined wealth of $5.7 trillion.
• U.S. commercial banks held assets totaling $22.9 trillion as of December 2022.
• U.S. global assets under management exceeded $30 trillion.
• During the Great Recession of 2008, the U.S. economy experienced a significant decline, prompting the enactment of the American Reinvestment and Recovery Act by Congress.
• Following the recession, the U.S. underwent the longest economic expansion on record, lasting until July 2019.
• The New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq are the world’s largest stock exchanges by market capitalization and trade volume.
• The U.S. holds the world’s largest gold reserves, with over 8,000 tonnes of gold.
• In 2014, the U.S. economy ranked first internationally in venture capital investment and global research and development funding.
• The U.S. invests approximately 3.46% of its GDP in cutting-edge research and development across various economic sectors.
• Consumer spending accounted for 68% of the U.S. economy in 2022.
• The labor share of income in the U.S. was 44% in 2021.
• The United States has the world’s largest consumer market.
• The U.S. labor market has attracted immigrants globally, resulting in one of the highest net migration rates worldwide.
• The U.S. economy ranks highly in global assessments such as the Ease of Doing Business Index and the Global Competitiveness Report.

• The article is part of a comprehensive series on the Economy of the United States, covering economic history topics such as agricultural history, banking history, petroleum history, shipbuilding, the Industrial Revolution, the history of the U.S. dollar, lumber history, tariff history, and economic history by state.

• The U.S. economy is analyzed across sectors including the primary sector (agriculture, energy, petroleum, electricity, mining, fishing, forestry, water and sanitation), secondary sector (automotive, iron and steel, pulp and paper), tertiary sector (social programs, transportation, tourism, education, gambling, healthcare, insurance), and financial services (central bank, banking, largest banks, stock exchanges).

• The economic performance and characteristics are also examined by state, including California, Texas, New York, Florida, among others, with state-level statistics on budgets, credit ratings, unemployment rates, and union membership.

• Economic data and analyses extend to cities and counties such as Allentown, Atlanta, Buffalo, Chicago, Cleveland, Columbus, Detroit, Door County, Erie, Houston, Indianapolis, Kansas City, Lexington, Long Island, Louisville, Memphis, New York City, Norfolk, Omaha, Philadelphia, Phoenix, Pittsburgh, Salt Lake City, San Diego, Spokane, St. Louis, Stamford, Youngstown, and Washington, D.C.
• Labor-related topics covered include labor law aspects such as child labor, labor unions, minimum wage, and right-to-work laws, as well as employment issues including causes of unemployment.
• The economic history of the United States originated with British settlements established along the Eastern seaboard during the 17th and 18th centuries.
• After the year 1700, the population of the American colonies increased rapidly, which corresponded with significant growth in both imports and exports.
• The colonies engaged in international trade involving Africa, Asia, and most frequently Europe, contributing to the economic development of the region.
• The 13 American colonies declared and gained independence from the British Empire in the late 18th century.
• Following independence, the economy of the former colonies transitioned from primarily colonial trade-based systems toward an economy increasingly focused on agriculture.
• Over a span of 180 years, the United States evolved into a vast, integrated, and industrialized economy, accounting for approximately one-fifth of the global economy by the end of the period.
• During this transformation, the U.S. GDP per capita surpassed that of many other nations, overtaking the British Empire as the leading economic power.
• The U.S. economy sustained high wage levels, which attracted millions of immigrants from across the world seeking better economic opportunities.
• In the 1820s and 1830s, the rise of mass production shifted the economic focus from artisanal craftsmanship to factory-based manufacturing.
• Government regulations introduced during this era strengthened patent protections, fostering innovation and industrial growth.
• At the beginning of the 19th century, over 80 percent of the American population was engaged in farming, reflecting a predominantly agrarian society.
• Early manufacturing primarily involved initial processing of raw materials, with key industries including lumber and sawmills, textiles, and the production of boots and shoes.
• The abundance of natural resources in the United States significantly contributed to the rapid economic expansion throughout the 19th century.
• The availability of ample land allowed the farming population to continue growing; however, sectors such as manufacturing, services, and transportation expanded at a much faster rate.
• By 1860, the rural population had decreased to about 50 percent, down from over 80 percent at the start of the century, indicating increasing urbanization and industrialization.
• The 19th century experienced frequent recessions that often coincided with financial crises, exemplified by the Panic of 1837.
• The Panic of 1837 triggered a prolonged five-year depression characterized by widespread bank failures and unprecedented levels of unemployment.
• Due to the extensive economic changes over the centuries, direct comparisons between the severity of early recessions and modern recessions are challenging.
• Post-World War II recessions appear to have been less severe than those in the 19th century, although the underlying reasons for this difference remain unclear.
• At the beginning of the 20th century, innovations and improvements in existing technologies enabled significant enhancements in the standard of living for American consumers.

• Many firms expanded by leveraging economies of scale and improved communication to operate nationwide, leading to industry concentration that raised concerns about monopolies potentially increasing prices and reducing output.
• Despite monopoly fears, many large firms rapidly cut costs, resulting in trends toward lower prices and increased output in their industries.
• Workers in these large firms often benefited from the firms' success, as these companies typically offered the highest wages globally.
• Since approximately 1890, the United States has held the position as the world’s largest national economy by gross domestic product (GDP).

• Following the Great Depression of the 1930s, the U.S. government intervened to strengthen the economy by increasing government spending, cutting taxes to stimulate consumer spending, and fostering rapid growth in the money supply to encourage further expenditure.

• Economic stabilization strategies evolved significantly from the 1930s to the 1980s, with national policymakers relying primarily on fiscal policy—from the New Deal era starting in 1933 through the Great Society initiatives of the 1960s—to influence economic activity.

• During the First and Second World Wars, the United States experienced better economic outcomes than other combatant nations because no battles occurred on its territory, including all then-48 states.
• Despite the absence of combat on U.S. soil, wartime sacrifices were substantial; at the peak of World War II, nearly 40 percent of U.S. GDP was allocated to war production.
• During World War II, large portions of the economy were directed toward military purposes, with nearly all relevant inputs allocated to the war effort.
• Wartime economic controls included rationing of many goods, price and wage controls, and cessation of production of many durable consumer goods.
• A significant share of the workforce was inducted into the military and paid half their civilian wages, with approximately half of those inducted sent into combat zones.

• The Keynesian economic approach, advocated by British economist John Maynard Keynes, emphasized a leading role for elected officials in directing the economy through control of government spending and taxation by the U.S. president and Congress.

• The "Baby Boom" period from 1942 to 1957 featured a dramatic increase in fertility rates, driven by delayed marriages and childbearing during the Great Depression, a surge in prosperity, increased demand for suburban single-family homes rather than inner-city apartments, and renewed optimism about the future.
• The Baby Boom peaked around 1957 and subsequently began to decline.

• After 1973, the U.S. experienced a period of high inflation, elevated interest rates, and increased unemployment, which eroded confidence in fiscal policy as an effective tool for regulating overall economic activity.
• Between 1946 and 1973, the U.S. economy grew at an average annual rate of 3.8%, while real median household income increased by 74%, equivalent to an average annual growth of 2.1%.

• Since the 1970s, several emerging countries have begun to narrow the economic gap with the United States, primarily by relocating manufacturing of goods formerly produced in the U.S. to countries where production costs were sufficiently lower to offset shipping costs and still yield higher profits.
• Additionally, some countries have gradually acquired the capability to produce products and services that were previously exclusive to the U.S. and a few other nations.
• Real income growth in the United States has slowed since the 1970s.
• During the 1970s and 1980s, there was widespread belief in the U.S. that Japan’s economy would surpass that of the United States; however, this outcome did not materialize.

• The United States economy experienced a recession in 2001 characterized by an unusually slow jobs recovery, with the number of jobs not returning to the February 2001 level until January 2005, a phenomenon termed a "jobless recovery."

• This jobless recovery coincided with the formation of a housing bubble and a broader debt bubble, as the ratio of household debt to GDP increased from a record 70% in the first quarter of 2001 to 99% in the first quarter of 2008.
• Homeowners increasingly borrowed against inflated home values, fueling consumption and driving up household debt levels, which temporarily boosted GDP but was unsustainable.

• Beginning in 2006, housing prices declined, causing a sharp fall in the value of mortgage-backed securities, which precipitated a crisis akin to a bank run in the largely unregulated non-depository banking sector that had expanded beyond the traditional regulated depository banks.
• The financial crisis intensified in 2007–2008, culminating in September 2008 with the bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers and government bailouts of several other financial institutions.

• The Bush administration (2001–2009) and Obama administration (2009–2017) responded with banking bailout programs and Keynesian fiscal stimulus involving high government deficits, while the Federal Reserve maintained near-zero interest rates to support economic recovery.
• Between 2009 and 2012, households reduced their debt levels, marking the only period since 1947 where this occurred, which had been a significant impediment to economic recovery.

• Key recovery milestones included real GDP regaining its pre-crisis late 2007 peak by 2011, household net worth recovering by the second quarter of 2012, non-farm payroll jobs returning to pre-recession levels by May 2014, and the unemployment rate normalizing by September 2015.
• Following these recoveries, each economic indicator continued to reach record levels, with the U.S. economic recovery becoming the second longest on record as of April 2018.
• The Great Recession, part of the 2008 financial crisis, saw a 5.0% decline in GDP from spring 2008 to spring 2009, making it the most severe recession since the mid-20th century.
• Other notable recessions included a 3.7% GDP contraction in 1957–1958, a 3.1% decline following the 1973 oil crisis from late 1973 to early 1975, and a 2.9% drop during the 1981–1982 recession.
• More recent mild recessions were the 1990–1991 downturn with a 1.3% output fall, and the brief 2001 recession lasting eight months with a 0.3% GDP decline.

• The most vigorous and sustained U.S. economic expansions in the 20th century were from early 1961 to mid-1969 with 53% growth (5.1% annually), mid-1991 to late 2000 with 43% growth (3.8% annually), and late 1982 to mid-1990 with 37% growth (4% annually).
• Public debt as a percentage of GDP rose steadily in the 21st century, increasing from 31% in 2000 to 52% in 2009, and reaching 77% by 2017.
• By 2017, the United States ranked 43rd highest in national debt out of 207 countries worldwide.

• In the first two quarters of 2020, during Donald Trump's presidency, the U.S. economy experienced significant setbacks beginning in March 2020 due to the novel coronavirus pandemic and the consequent shutdown of major sectors of the American economy.
• As of March 2020, U.S. exports of automobiles and industrial machines plummeted as a direct result of the global pandemic.

• Social distancing measures implemented in March 2020 negatively impacted demand for goods and services, leading to a 4.8% annualized decline in U.S. GDP in the first quarter of 2020, marking the steepest contraction since the fourth quarter of 2008.
• U.S. retail sales dropped by a record 8.7% in March 2020 alone, reflecting the severe economic disruption.
• The U.S. airline industry suffered a sharp decline in revenues due to the pandemic-induced travel restrictions and reduced demand.
• The COVID-19 recession has been widely characterized as the most severe global economic downturn since the Great Depression and significantly worse than the Great Recession.
• Midtown Manhattan, identified as the world’s largest central business district, was notably impacted by the economic downturn.
• By May 2020, CNN analysis of unemployment data suggested that the U.S. economy was potentially in its worst condition since the 1930s.
• On May 8, 2020, the U.S. reached a record unemployment rate of 14.7%, with 20.5 million jobs lost in April 2020 alone.

• Jerome Powell, Chairman of the U.S. Federal Reserve, warned in May 2020 that full economic recovery could take an extended time, with expectations of prolonged weak economic growth, low productivity growth, and stagnant incomes.
• By May 31, 2020, over 40 million Americans had filed for unemployment benefits, underscoring the scale of job losses.
• In June 2020, the decline in U.S. continental flights due to the pandemic led the U.S. government to temporarily halt services of fifteen airlines to 75 domestic airports.
• On June 10, 2020, The New York Times reported that the U.S. budget deficit had grown to a record $1.88 trillion for the first eight months of the 2020 fiscal year.
• The U.S. economy recovered in 2021, growing by 5.7%, marking its best annual performance since the presidency of Ronald Reagan (1981–1989).

• The period from 2021 to 2022 saw a historic surge in inflation in the United States, with the Consumer Price Index inflation rate reaching 9.1% in June 2022 compared to June 2021, representing a 41-year high.
• Critics attributed the inflation surge to various factors, including policies of the Federal Reserve.
• By April 2023, the inflation rate had decreased to 4.9%, which remained approximately 3% above the Federal Reserve’s target inflation rate of 2%.

• The table presents the main economic indicators of the United States from 1980 to 2023, with International Monetary Fund (IMF) staff estimates for 2024 to 2029, including GDP (both in billion US$ PPP and nominal), GDP per capita (in US$ PPP and nominal), real GDP growth, inflation rate, unemployment rate, and government debt as a percentage of GDP.

• In 1980, the US GDP was 2,857.3 billion US$ PPP and nominal, with a GDP per capita of 12,552.9 US$ PPP and nominal; the real GDP growth was −0.3%, inflation was 13.5%, unemployment was 7.2%, and government debt data was not available.

• From 1981 to 1989, GDP increased steadily from 3,207.0 billion to 5,641.6 billion US$ PPP and nominal, with GDP per capita rising from 13,948.7 to 22,814.1 US$ PPP and nominal; real GDP growth fluctuated between −1.8% and 7.2%, inflation rates decreased from 10.4% to 4.8%, unemployment declined from 7.6% to 5.3%, and government debt data remained unavailable.

• The early 1990s saw GDP growth slow, with 1991 showing a slight contraction of −0.1%, GDP at 6,158.1 billion US$, and inflation dropping to 4.2%; unemployment rose to 6.9%, and government debt data was still not reported.

• Throughout the 1990s, GDP and GDP per capita continued to grow, reaching 9,631.2 billion US$ and 34,496.2 US$ per capita in 1999, respectively; real GDP growth averaged around 2.7% to 4.8%, inflation remained below 3.4%, unemployment decreased to 4.2%, and government debt data was still not available.
• In 2000, GDP reached 10,251.0 billion US$, GDP per capita 36,312.8 US$, with 4.1% real growth, 3.4% inflation, 4.0% unemployment, and government debt at 53.1% of GDP.

• From 2001 to 2007, GDP rose from 10,581.9 billion to 14,474.3 billion US$, GDP per capita increased from 37,101.5 to 47,943.4 US$, real GDP growth varied between 1.0% and 3.9%, inflation ranged from 1.6% to 3.4%, unemployment decreased from 4.7% to 4.6%, and government debt increased from 53.1% to 64.6% of GDP.

• The 2008 financial crisis saw GDP growth nearly stagnate at 0.1%, inflation at 3.8%, unemployment rise to 5.8%, and government debt jump to 73.5% of GDP, with GDP at 14,769.9 billion US$ and GDP per capita at 48,470.6 US$.
• In 2009, GDP contracted by −2.6% to 14,478.1 billion US$, inflation was negative at −0.3% (deflation), unemployment surged to 9.3%, and government debt rose sharply to 86.7% of GDP.
• Recovery began in 2010 with GDP growth of 2.7%, inflation at 1.6%, unemployment at 9.6%, and government debt reaching 95.2% of GDP; GDP was 15,049.0 billion US$, and GDP per capita 48,586.3 US$.

• From 2011 to 2019, GDP steadily increased from 15,599.7 billion to 21,539.9 billion US$, GDP per capita rose from 50,008.1 to 65,561.3 US$, real GDP growth ranged from 1.6% to 3.0%, inflation remained low between 0.1% and 3.1%, unemployment decreased significantly from 8.9% to 3.7%, and government debt rose gradually from 99.5% to 108% of GDP.

• The COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 caused a GDP contraction of −2.2% to 21,354.1 billion US$, inflation was low at 1.2%, unemployment spiked to 8.1%, and government debt surged to 131.8% of GDP; GDP per capita was 64,461.6 US$.

• In 2021, GDP rebounded strongly with 6.1% growth to 23,681.1 billion US$, inflation increased to 4.7%, unemployment decreased to 5.4%, and government debt slightly declined to 124.5% of GDP; GDP per capita reached 71,257.9 US$.

• By 2022, GDP grew to 26,006.9 billion US$ with 2.5% real growth, inflation rose sharply to 8.0%, unemployment fell to 3.6%, and government debt decreased to 118.6% of GDP; GDP per capita was 77,979.8 US$.
• In 2023, GDP reached 27,720.7 billion US$, GDP per capita 82,715.1 US$, real GDP growth was 2.9%, inflation moderated to 4.1%, unemployment remained at 3.6%, and government debt was 118.7% of GDP.

• IMF staff projections for 2024 to 2029 forecast continuous GDP growth from 29,167.7 billion US$ in 2024 to 35,457.9 billion US$ in 2029, with GDP per capita rising from 86,601.2 US$ to 102,987.0 US$ over the same period.

• Projected real GDP growth rates for 2024–2029 range from 2.0% to 2.8%, inflation rates are expected to remain low between 1.9% and 2.9%, unemployment rates are forecasted between 4.0% and 4.4%, and government debt is projected to increase from 121% to 131.7% of GDP.
• Inflation rates below 5% are highlighted in green in the table, indicating periods of relatively low inflation throughout the data range.
• The table also notes occurrences of deflation and year-over-year increases in the M2 money supply, though specific yearly data for these are not detailed in the summary.
• In Q3 2023, private sector workers in the United States earned approximately $2 trillion, accounting for about 29.6% of all money earned before taxes during that quarter.
• The U.S. nominal GDP was $19.5 trillion in 2017, making it the largest economy in the world by nominal terms at that time.
• In Q1 2018, the annualized nominal GDP of the United States reached $20.1 trillion, marking the first time it exceeded the $20 trillion threshold.

• The composition of U.S. GDP is approximately 70% personal consumption, 18% business investment, 17% government spending (federal, state, and local, excluding transfer payments such as Social Security), and a negative 3% from net exports due to the trade deficit.
• Real GDP growth rates were 2.3% in 2017, 1.5% in 2016, and 2.9% in 2015, indicating fluctuating but generally positive economic growth during these years.
• Quarterly annualized real GDP growth rates in 2018 were 2.2% in Q1, 4.2% in Q2, 3.4% in Q3, and 2.2% in Q4; notably, the 4.2% growth in Q2 2018 was the best quarterly rate since Q3 2014.
• The overall real GDP growth for 2018 was 2.9%, representing the best annual economic performance in the United States in a decade.
• The COVID-19 pandemic caused a significant contraction in U.S. GDP in 2020, with quarterly annualized growth rates of −5.0% in Q1 and −32.9% in Q2, reflecting a sharp economic downturn.
• In 2014, China surpassed the United States as the largest economy by GDP measured at purchasing power parity (PPP), ending over a century during which the U.S. held the highest GDP (PPP) figures.
• Over the past 40 years leading up to 2014, China’s GDP growth rate more than tripled that of the United States, contributing to its rise in PPP terms.
• As of 2017, the European Union collectively had a GDP approximately 5% larger than that of the United States; however, the EU is a political union rather than a single country.
• Despite the EU’s aggregate GDP, the United States remained the world’s largest economy by nominal GDP in 2017.
• Real GDP per capita in the United States, measured in 2009 dollars, was $52,444 in 2017 and had been increasing annually since 2010.
• Average annual growth rates of real GDP per capita in the U.S. were 3.0% in the 1960s, 2.1% in the 1970s, 2.4% in the 1980s, 2.2% in the 1990s, 0.7% in the 2000s, and 0.9% from 2010 to 2017.

• Economists debate the causes of slower GDP per capita growth since 2000, citing factors such as aging demographics, slower population and labor force growth, reduced productivity growth, decreased corporate investment, greater income inequality reducing demand, lack of major innovations, and diminished labor power.
• In 2017, the United States ranked 20th out of 220 countries in GDP per capita.
• Among modern U.S. Presidents, Bill Clinton achieved the highest cumulative percentage increase in real GDP during his two terms, followed by Ronald Reagan in second place and Barack Obama in third.
• According to the World Bank, U.S. real GDP grew at an average annual rate of 1.7% from 2000 to the first half of 2014, which is approximately half the historical average growth rate prior to 2000.
• According to the US Census Bureau in 2019, data on the number of businesses by type was collected, providing a foundational understanding of the economic structure in the United States.
• In 2015, the nominal GDP sector composition for the world and the United States was measured in millions of dollars at 2005 constant prices, allowing for inflation-adjusted comparisons.

• The total real GDP of the world in 2015 was $60,093,221 million, with the agricultural sector contributing $1,968,215 million, the industrial sector $16,453,140 million, and the services sector $38,396,695 million.

• In the same year, the United States had a real GDP of $15,160,104 million, with agriculture accounting for $149,023 million, industry for $3,042,332 million, and services for $11,518,980 million, indicating a dominant services sector.
• For 2016, the nominal GDP sector composition of the United States was reported in millions of dollars at current prices, reflecting the economic values without inflation adjustment.

• The United States' nominal GDP in 2016 was $18,624,450 million, with the agricultural sector contributing $204,868.95 million, the industrial sector $3,613,143.3 million, and the services sector $14,806,437.75 million.
• The sectoral percentages for the 2016 nominal GDP data were sourced from the CIA World Factbook, ensuring reliability and consistency in the economic statistics presented.
• The JOLTS report provides key labor market indicators including total unemployed people, total job openings, and total quits, reflecting the dynamics of employment in the United States.

• Job growth by U.S. presidents is measured as the cumulative percentage change from the month after inauguration to the end of the presidential term, with data illustrated in a panel chart covering nine key economic variables annually from 2014 to 2017.
• The years 2014 to 2016 correspond to President Barack Obama’s second term, while 2017 falls under President Donald Trump’s term, with detailed citations available on the referenced detail page.
• In 2017, the U.S. labor force comprised approximately 160.4 million people, ranking as the fourth largest labor force globally after China, India, and the European Union.
• In 2010, government employment (federal, state, and local) accounted for 22 million workers within the U.S. labor market.
• Small businesses represent the largest employer category in the U.S., employing 37% of American workers, followed closely by large businesses which employ 36% of the workforce.
• White collar workers constituted 44% of the U.S. workforce as of 2022, marking an increase from 34% in the year 2000.
• The private sector employs 85% of working Americans, while government employment accounts for 14% of all U.S. workers.
• Over 99% of all private employing organizations in the U.S. are classified as small businesses, totaling approximately 30 million entities.
• Small businesses are responsible for 64% of net job creation (jobs created minus jobs lost) and accounted for 70% of all jobs created in the last decade.

• The employment proportion between small and large businesses has remained relatively stable annually, with some small businesses growing into large enterprises and just over half of small businesses surviving beyond five years.

• Among large businesses, several of the world’s largest companies and employers are American, including Walmart, which is the largest company and largest private sector employer globally, employing 2.1 million people worldwide and 1.4 million in the U.S. alone.
• According to the U.S. Census Bureau data on the number of employees per business, since the 1970s there has been a decoupling of wage gains from worker productivity in the United States.

• Minority-owned businesses, owned by Hispanics, African Americans, Asian Americans, and Native Americans who constitute 35% of the U.S. population, number approximately 4.1 million and generate nearly $700 billion in revenue while employing almost five million workers.
• Americans have the highest average employee income among OECD nations, with the median household income recorded at $52,029 in 2008.
• Approximately 284,000 working Americans hold two full-time jobs, and 7.6 million have part-time jobs in addition to their full-time employment.
• Labor union membership comprises 12% of all working individuals in the U.S., with the majority of union members employed in government positions.
• The decline in union membership over recent decades parallels a decrease in labor’s share of the economy.
• The World Bank ranks the United States first globally in the ease of hiring and firing workers.

• The United States is unique among advanced economies in not legally guaranteeing paid vacation or paid sick days, and is one of the few countries worldwide, alongside Papua New Guinea, Suriname, and Liberia, without a legal right to paid family leave.
• The International Trade Union Confederation assigned the U.S. a grade of 4 out of 5+ in 2014 and again in 2020 for workers’ rights, representing the third-lowest score on their scale.
• A 2023 Oxfam study ranked the United States among the worst developed countries in terms of labor protections.

• Scholars such as business theorist Jeffrey Pfeffer and political scientist Daniel Kinderman argue that contemporary U.S. employment practices—characterized by increased managerial performance pressure, toxic work environments, job precarity, and long working hours—may cause approximately 120,000 excess deaths annually, making the workplace the fifth leading cause of death in the country.

• As of December 2017, the official U.S. unemployment rate was 4.1%, corresponding to 6.6 million unemployed individuals within a civilian labor force of approximately 160.6 million people, relative to a total U.S. population of about 327 million.
• The broader U-6 unemployment rate, which includes part-time workers who are underemployed, stood at 8.1% or 8.2 million people as of December 2017.

• Between 2009 and 2010, in the aftermath of the Great Recession, the U.S. experienced jobless recoveries characterized by record levels of long-term unemployment, with more than six million workers unemployed for over six months as of January 2010, disproportionately affecting older workers.

• One year after the recession officially ended in June 2009, immigrant employment increased by 656,000 jobs, while U.S.-born workers lost over one million jobs, influenced by demographic trends including an aging population and a higher number of white retirees.
• In April 2010, the official unemployment rate was 9.9%, whereas the broader U-6 unemployment rate was significantly higher at 17.1%.

• From February 2008 to February 2010, the number of people working part-time for economic reasons (preferring full-time work) rose by 4.0 million to 8.8 million, representing an 83% increase in part-time workers during this two-year period.

• By 2013, although the official unemployment rate had dropped below 8%, the labor market still exhibited characteristics of a jobless recovery, including a record proportion of long-term unemployed individuals and declining household incomes.
• The total number of payroll jobs in the U.S. economy returned to its pre-recession level (November 2007) by May 2014, signaling economic recovery.

• Historically, the U.S. unemployment rate was higher in the post-World War II period but fell below the rising eurozone unemployment rate by the mid-1980s and has remained significantly lower almost continuously since then.

• Employment sector shifts from 1955 to 1980 show a transition from agriculture and industry to services: in 1955, 55% of Americans worked in services, 30–35% in industry, and 10–15% in agriculture; by 1980, over 65% were employed in services, 25–30% in industry, and less than 5% in agriculture.
• Male unemployment rates have consistently been higher than female rates, with figures in 2009 showing 9.8% for males versus 7.5% for females.
• Unemployment rates among Caucasians have remained much lower than those of African Americans, with 2009 rates at 8.5% for Caucasians compared to 15.8% for African Americans.
• Youth unemployment reached 18.5% in July 2009, marking the highest rate for that month since 1948.
• The unemployment rate for young African Americans was notably high at 28.2% in May 2013.
• The U.S. unemployment rate peaked at an all-time high of 14.7% in April 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, before declining to 11.1% by June 2020.
• The economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic included a 32.9% contraction in U.S. GDP during the second quarter of 2020.
• Following the peak in 2020, the unemployment rate rapidly declined to 3.9% in 2021.
• By May 2023, the U.S. unemployment rate further decreased to 3.7%.
• In 2012, employment in the United States was distributed across three primary economic sectors: the service sector, the manufacturing sector, and the agriculture sector.
• The service sector accounted for the largest share of U.S. employment, comprising 79.7% of the workforce.
• The manufacturing sector represented 19.2% of total employment in the United States during the same year.
• The agriculture sector employed the smallest proportion of the workforce, making up only 1.1% of total U.S. employment in 2012.
• Median personal income after taxes reflects the average earnings individuals retain following the deduction of various taxes, including federal, state, and payroll taxes.
• State income tax varies significantly across the United States, with some states imposing no income tax while others have progressive tax rates that impact the net income of residents.
• Payroll tax on the employee side consists of mandatory contributions deducted from wages to fund Social Security and Medicare programs, directly reducing take-home pay.

• Federal income tax is a progressive tax levied by the U.S. government on individual and household earnings, with rates increasing as income rises, thereby affecting median personal income after taxes.

• Median income after tax represents the midpoint of income distribution after all applicable taxes (federal, state, and payroll) have been subtracted, providing a more accurate measure of disposable income.

• Payroll tax on the employer side involves additional contributions made by employers to Social Security and Medicare, which, while not deducted from employee wages, represent a significant labor cost.

• U.S. real median household income data from 1984 to 2021 illustrates trends in inflation-adjusted earnings over nearly four decades, highlighting periods of growth, stagnation, or decline in household purchasing power.

• The Federal Reserve Survey of Consumer Finances provides detailed data on U.S. family pre-tax income and net worth distribution for the years 2013 and 2016, offering insights into wealth inequality and economic status across different population segments.
• Real median household income in the United States, adjusted for inflation and considered a reliable indicator of middle-class income, reached $59,039 in 2016, marking a record high.

• The 2016 median household income was only slightly above the previous peak recorded in 1998, suggesting that the purchasing power of middle-class family income has remained stagnant or declined over approximately two decades.
• In 2013, total employee compensation in the U.S. amounted to $8.969 trillion, while gross private investment was recorded at $2.781 trillion.
• Among OECD countries, Americans possess the highest average household income.
• In 2010, the United States held the fourth-highest median household income among OECD nations, a decline from the second-highest position it occupied in 2007.

• An analysis indicated that by 2010, middle-class incomes in the United States were on par with those in Canada, and projections suggested that by 2014, U.S. middle-class incomes may have fallen behind Canadian levels.
• Several other advanced economies have narrowed the income gap with the United States in recent years, reflecting changing international income dynamics.

• Income inequality in the United States has fluctuated significantly since around 1915, exhibiting peaks in the 1920s and 2000s, with a notable period of lower inequality from approximately 1950 to 1980 known as the Great Compression, followed by a trend of increasing inequality termed the great divergence.

• Among post-industrialized peer countries, the U.S. exhibits the highest level of income inequality; while pre-tax and transfer income inequality is comparable to other developed nations, the U.S. shows substantially higher inequality after taxes and transfers, indicating less redistribution from higher to lower income households.

• In 2016, average market income for the lowest income quintile was $15,600, whereas the highest quintile averaged $280,300; within the top quintile, inequality intensified, with the top 1% earning approximately $1.8 million, about 30 times the $59,300 income of the middle quintile.

• Economic and political consequences of income inequality in the U.S. may include slower GDP growth, diminished income mobility, elevated poverty rates, increased household debt usage raising financial crisis risks, and heightened political polarization.

• Contributing factors to rising inequality encompass increasing executive compensation relative to average workers, financialization of the economy, greater industry concentration, declining unionization rates, lower effective tax rates on higher incomes, and technological changes favoring individuals with higher educational attainment.

• Measurement of income inequality is subject to debate due to variations across datasets and differences in whether income is measured as cash compensation (market income) or after taxes and transfers; the Gini coefficient is a widely accepted metric ranging from 0 (perfect equality) to 1 (maximum inequality).

• Key data sources for income inequality measurement include the Congressional Budget Office (CBO), Internal Revenue Service (IRS), and U.S. Census Bureau; according to the Census Bureau, the Gini coefficient for pre-tax money income reached a record 0.485 in 2018, rising to 0.488 in 2020 and 0.494 in 2021.

• U.S. tax and transfer policies are progressive, generally reducing effective income inequality by imposing higher tax rates on higher incomes; the lowest earning workers, particularly those with dependents, often pay no income taxes and may receive subsidies via child credits and the Earned Income Tax Credit.

• According to CBO data, the U.S. Gini coefficient based on market income was 0.59 in 2016 but decreased to 0.42 after accounting for taxes and transfers, demonstrating the redistributive effect of fiscal policy.

• The top 1% share of market income increased from 9.6% in 1979 to a peak of 20.7% in 2007, then declined to 17.5% by 2016; after taxes and transfers, these shares were 7.4% in 1979, 16.6% in 2007, and 12.5% in 2016, reflecting the impact of taxation and social programs on income distribution.

sections.section_name: Household net worth and wealth inequality
openai_summarised_points: • As of Q4 2017, total household net worth in the United States reached a record $99 trillion, marking an increase of $5.2 trillion from 2016, driven by gains in both the stock market and housing prices.
• The total household net worth has been setting records continuously since Q4 2012.
• When divided evenly, the $99 trillion equates to an average net worth of $782,000 per household, based on approximately 126.2 million households, or $302,000 per person.
• The median household net worth in 2016 was significantly lower at $97,300, indicating that half of U.S. families had net worth above this amount and half below.
• The bottom 25% of families had a median net worth of zero, while families in the 25th to 50th percentile had a median net worth of $40,000.
• Wealth inequality in the U.S. is more pronounced than income inequality; in 2012, the top 1% of households owned about 42% of the net worth, up from 24% in 1979.
• A September 2017 Federal Reserve report highlighted that wealth inequality was at record highs, with the top 1% controlling 38.6% of the country's wealth in 2016.
• The Boston Consulting Group projected in a June 2017 report that by 2021, 1% of Americans would control 70% of the country's wealth.
• The wealthiest 10% of households possess 80% of all financial assets in the United States.
• U.S. wealth inequality exceeds that of most developed countries, with the exception of Sweden.

• Inherited wealth contributes significantly to wealth disparities, as many wealthy Americans have had a "substantial head start"; in September 2012, the Institute for Policy Studies reported that over 60% of the Forbes richest 400 Americans grew up in substantial privilege.
• Median household wealth declined by 35% from $106,591 in 2005 to $68,839 in 2011 due to the Great Recession but has since recovered as indicated by later data.
• Approximately 30% of the world's millionaire population resided in the United States as of 2009.
• The Economist Intelligence Unit estimated in 2008 that there were 16,600,000 millionaires in the U.S.
• In 2011, 34% of the world's billionaires were American.
• The U.S. home ownership rate in the first quarter of 2018 was 64.2%, significantly below the all-time peak of 69.2% recorded in the fourth quarter of 2004 during a housing bubble.
• During the Great Recession of 2007–2009, millions of homes were lost to foreclosure, causing the home ownership rate to decline to a trough of 62.9% in the second quarter of 2016.
• The average home ownership rate in the United States from 1965 to 2017 was 65.3%.

• The average home in the United States provides more than 700 square feet (65 square meters) per person, which is 50% to 100% larger than the average living space per person in other high-income countries.
• Ownership rates of gadgets and amenities in U.S. households are relatively high compared to other countries.
• According to a 2016 report by Pew Research Center, for the first time in 130 years, Americans aged 18 to 34 are more likely to live with their parents than in any other housing arrangement.
• A study by ATTOM Data Solutions found that in 70% of the counties surveyed, homes are becoming increasingly unaffordable for the average U.S. worker.
• As of 2018, the number of U.S. citizens living in their vehicles increased in major cities with significantly higher than average housing costs, including Los Angeles, Portland, and San Francisco.
• CNBC reported that the median sale price for a U.S. home in 2017 was US$199,200.
• By February 2023, the median U.S. home sale price had risen to US$392,000, according to Statista.
• The United States faces a nationwide housing shortage caused by insufficient housing construction, which declined sharply after the 2008 Great Recession.

• This housing shortage has led to rising rents and home prices, making housing increasingly unaffordable; one estimate placed the shortage at 3.8 million units in 2019, with the shortage worsening during and since the COVID-19 pandemic.
• As of January 2024, in approximately half of U.S. cities, workers require incomes of $100,000 or more to afford purchasing a home, driven by rising housing prices and increased interest rates.
• Real wages, defined as wages adjusted for inflation, for most workers in the United States and median incomes have either declined or remained stagnant over the past twenty to forty years.
• A 2020 microanalysis revealed that over the preceding four decades, labor's share of national output declined while the profit share of the same output increased.
• In 1970, wages accounted for more than 51% of U.S. GDP, with profits less than 5%; by 2013, wages had decreased to 44% of the economy, while profits more than doubled to 11%.
• Inflation-adjusted ("real") per capita disposable personal income in the U.S. rose steadily from 1945 to 2008 but has generally remained level since then.

• In 2005, median personal income for individuals over 18 varied significantly, ranging from $3,317 for an unemployed, married Asian American female to $55,935 for a full-time, year-round employed Asian American male.
• According to the U.S. Census in 2005, men generally earned higher incomes than women, and Asians and Whites earned more than African Americans and Hispanics.
• The overall median personal income for all individuals over 18 in 2005 was $24,062, increasing to $32,140 for those aged 25 or above.
• The federal minimum wage rate was $7.25 per hour in both 2009 and 2017, equating to $15,080 annually for a typical 2,080-hour work year.
• The minimum wage level is slightly above the poverty threshold for a single-person household but approximately 50% of the poverty level for a family of four.
• A Pew Research Center report from October 2014 indicated that real wages have been flat or declining for most U.S. workers over the last five decades, despite job growth.
• Bloomberg reported in July 2018 that real GDP per capita has grown substantially since the Great Recession, indicating economic growth not reflected in wage increases.

• An August 2017 CareerBuilder survey found that 80% of U.S. workers live paycheck to paycheck; spokesman Mike Erwin attributed this to stagnant wages and rising costs of education and consumer goods.

• A federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau survey revealed that roughly half of U.S. citizens have difficulty paying bills, and more than one-third have faced hardships such as inability to afford housing, food shortages, or insufficient funds for medical care.

• Journalist and author Alissa Quart stated that the cost of living is rapidly outpacing salary and wage growth, including in traditionally secure professions like teaching, noting that middle-class life is now 30% more expensive than it was 20 years ago.

• The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported in February 2019 that seven million U.S. citizens were three months or more behind on car payments, a record level signaling financial distress despite low unemployment.
• A May 2019 NPR poll found that among rural Americans, 40% struggle to pay for healthcare, food, and housing, and 49% could not pay cash for a $1,000 emergency, opting instead to borrow money.

• Experts have described the U.S. economic recovery post-Great Recession as a "two-tier recovery," benefiting 60% of the population while 40% remain financially strained due to stagnant wages, rising housing, education, and healthcare costs, and increasing debt.

• A 2021 study by the National Low Income Housing Coalition determined that workers need to earn at least $24.90 per hour to afford renting a standard two-bedroom home and $20.40 per hour for a one-bedroom home anywhere in the U.S.; the two-bedroom wage requirement is 3.4 times the current federal minimum wage.
• The U.S. Census Bureau reported in September 2023 that incomes fell by 2.3% from 2021, marking the third consecutive year of income decline.

• Starting in the 1980s, relative poverty rates in the United States have consistently exceeded those of other wealthy nations, although analyses using a common data set for comparisons indicate that the U.S. has a lower absolute poverty rate by market income than most other wealthy countries.

• Extreme poverty in the United States, defined as households living on less than $2 per day before government benefits, doubled from 1996 levels to 1.5 million households in 2011, including 2.8 million children.
• In 2013, child poverty reached record high levels, with 16.7 million children living in food-insecure households, representing about a 35% increase compared to 2007 levels.
• As of 2015, 44 percent of children in the United States lived in low-income families.
• In 2016, 12.7% of the U.S. population lived in poverty, a decrease from 13.5% in 2015.
• The poverty rate rose from 12.5% in 2007, prior to the Great Recession, to a peak of 15.1% in 2010, before declining to just above the 2007 level.
• Between 1959 and 1962, the poverty rate was over 20%, but it declined to an all-time low of 11.1% in 1973 following the War on Poverty initiated during President Lyndon Johnson’s administration.
• In June 2016, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) warned the United States that its high poverty rate required urgent attention.
• Wealth inequality in the United States increased between 1989 and 2013.
• The population living in extreme-poverty neighborhoods increased by one third from 2000 to 2009.

• Residents of extreme-poverty neighborhoods typically experience inadequate access to quality education, higher crime rates, elevated rates of physical and psychological ailments, limited access to credit and wealth accumulation, higher prices for goods and services, and constrained access to job opportunities.
• As of 2013, 44% of America’s poor were considered to be in "deep poverty," defined as having an income 50% or more below the government’s official poverty line.

• According to the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development’s Annual Homeless Assessment Report, as of 2024, there were approximately 771,480 homeless people in the United States on a given night, equating to about 23 homeless individuals per 10,000 people.

• Nearly two-thirds of the homeless population stayed in emergency shelters or transitional housing programs, while about one-third lived on the street, in abandoned buildings, or other places not meant for human habitation.
• Between October 1, 2008, and September 30, 2009, about 1.56 million people (approximately 0.5% of the U.S. population) used an emergency shelter or transitional housing program.
• Around 44% of homeless people in the United States are employed.
• Homelessness increased from 2016 to 2020, accompanied by a rise in deaths among the homeless population.

• The United States possesses one of the least extensive social safety nets among developed countries, reducing both relative and absolute poverty by considerably less than the average for wealthy nations.
• Some experts argue that those living in poverty in the U.S. endure conditions comparable to those in developing countries.
• A May 2018 report by the United Nations Special Rapporteur on extreme poverty and human rights found that over five million people in the United States live in "Third World" conditions.
• Poverty is identified as the fourth leading risk factor for premature death annually, according to a 2023 study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association (JAMA).

• Over the past three decades, poor Americans have been incarcerated at much higher rates than their counterparts in other developed nations, with penal confinement described as "commonplace for poor men of working age."

• Some scholars argue that the shift toward neoliberal social and economic policies beginning in the late 1970s expanded the penal state, retrenched the social welfare state, deregulated the economy, and criminalized poverty, thereby transforming the experience and meaning of poverty in America.

• Sociologist Matthew Desmond, in his 2023 book *Poverty, by America*, states that the U.S. offers some of the lowest wages in the industrialized world, which has increased the number of working poor, most of whom are aged thirty-five or older.
• Social scientist Mark Robert Rank contends that the high poverty rates in the United States can largely be explained by structural failures at both economic and political levels.

• In 2016, the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) estimated that the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, was responsible for providing health insurance coverage to 23 million individuals through health insurance exchanges and Medicaid expansion programs.

• A comparative chart of OECD countries as of 2015 illustrates that the United States is an outlier, exhibiting significantly higher per capita health care spending while having a below-average life expectancy at birth relative to other member countries.

• A bar chart comparing healthcare expenditures as a percentage of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) across OECD countries highlights the United States as having the highest healthcare costs relative to its GDP among these nations.

• Historical data on the number and rate of uninsured individuals in the United States through 2016 is presented, alongside two CBO forecasts projecting uninsured rates through 2026 under two policy scenarios: one based on 2016 policies under President Obama and another based on 2018 policies under President Trump.

• The CBO forecasts indicate an increase in the number of uninsured persons under President Trump’s administration due primarily to two policy changes: first, the elimination of the individual mandate requiring health insurance coverage; and second, the cessation of cost-sharing reduction payments to insurers.
• The article notes that sections related to uninsured statistics require updating to reflect recent events or newly available data, with this notice dating back to October 2016.

• The American healthcare system comprises a combination of public and private insurance coverage, with the government providing insurance for approximately 53 million elderly individuals through Medicare, 62 million lower-income persons via Medicaid, and 15 million military veterans through the Veteran's Administration.

• Approximately 178 million individuals employed by companies receive subsidized health insurance through their employers, while an additional 52 million people purchase insurance directly either through the subsidized marketplace exchanges established under the Affordable Care Act (ACA) or directly from private insurers.
• Healthcare services in the United States are predominantly delivered by the private sector, except within the Veteran's Administration, where doctors are government employees.

• Multiple surveys indicate that the number of uninsured Americans decreased between 2013 and 2016, largely due to expanded Medicaid eligibility and the establishment of health insurance exchanges under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as "Obamacare."

• According to the United States Census Bureau, in 2012, 45.6 million people in the U.S., representing 14.8% of the under-65 population, were uninsured; by 2016, this number had declined by 18.3 million (a 40% reduction) to 27.3 million, or 8.6% of the under-65 population.

• Under President Donald Trump's administration, these gains in healthcare coverage began to reverse; the Commonwealth Fund estimated in May 2018 that the number of uninsured increased by four million from early 2016 to early 2018.
• The uninsured rate rose from 12.7% in 2016 to 15.5% in 2018, with a disproportionately greater impact on lower-income adults who exhibited higher uninsured rates compared to higher-income adults.

• Regionally, the South and West of the United States experienced higher uninsured rates than the North and East, and the 18 states that did not expand Medicaid under the ACA had higher uninsured rates than those that did expand Medicaid.
• Physicians for a National Health Program estimate that the lack of insurance coverage causes approximately 48,000 unnecessary deaths annually in the United States.

• The methodology of Physicians for a National Health Program has been criticized by John C. Goodman for failing to consider cause of death or to track changes in insurance status over time, including at the time of death.
• A 2009 study by Richard Kronick, a former policy adviser to President Bill Clinton, found no increased mortality associated with being uninsured after controlling for certain risk factors.

• The United States lags behind in overall healthcare performance but is recognized as a global leader in medical innovation, having solely developed or significantly contributed to nine of the top ten most important medical innovations since 1975, as ranked by a 2001 poll of physicians; in comparison, the European Union and Switzerland together contributed to five of these innovations.
• Since 1966, Americans have been awarded more Nobel Prizes in Medicine than the rest of the world combined, highlighting the country's dominance in medical research and discovery.

• Between 1989 and 2002, private biotechnology companies in the United States received four times more investment capital than their European counterparts, indicating a strong financial commitment to biotech innovation in America.

• A 2013 study by the National Institutes of Health examining 17 high-income countries found that the United States ranked at or near the top for negative health and social indicators, including obesity rate, frequency of automobile use and accidents, homicides, infant mortality rate, incidence of heart and lung disease, sexually transmitted infections, adolescent pregnancies, recreational drug or alcohol deaths, injuries, and rates of disability.

• These adverse lifestyle and societal factors contribute to the United States ranking at the bottom among these countries for life expectancy; specifically, the average American male is expected to live nearly four fewer years than males in the top-ranked country.
• Despite lower overall life expectancy, Americans who reach age 75 tend to live longer than their counterparts in peer nations.

• Cigarette consumption is a significant contributor to many health issues in the U.S., with Americans smoking 258 billion cigarettes in 2016; the economic impact of smoking amounts to $326 billion annually, comprising $170 billion in direct healthcare costs and $156 billion in lost productivity.

• A comprehensive 2007 study conducted by European doctors found that the five-year cancer survival rate in the United States was significantly higher than in all 21 European nations studied, with rates of 66.3% for men compared to the European mean of 47.3%, and 62.9% for women compared to 52.8% in Europe.
• Americans undergo cancer screenings at significantly higher rates than individuals in other developed countries and have the highest access to MRI and CT scans among OECD nations.

• Patients in the U.S. diagnosed with high cholesterol or hypertension are more likely to receive pharmaceutical treatments and successfully control these conditions compared to patients in other developed countries.
• Diabetic patients in the United States are more likely to receive treatment and meet treatment targets than those in Canada, England, or Scotland.

• According to a 2018 study analyzing 2016 data by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation, the United States ranked 27th globally in healthcare and education, a decline from its 6th place ranking in 1990.
• In 2015, U.S. healthcare costs accounted for 16.9% of GDP, which is over 5% of GDP higher than the next most expensive OECD country, according to the OECD.

• The 5% GDP difference in healthcare spending between the U.S. and the next highest OECD country represents approximately $1 trillion, equating to about $3,000 more per person and roughly one-third higher relative to the next most expensive country.

• Multiple factors contribute to the high cost of healthcare in the United States, including technological advances, administrative costs, drug pricing, higher charges by suppliers for medical equipment, and the greater volume of medical care received by Americans compared to other countries.

• Additional contributors to elevated healthcare costs in the U.S. are the relatively high wages of doctors, government regulations, the impact of lawsuits, and third-party payment systems that shield consumers from the full cost of treatments.
• Government healthcare plans in the U.S. tend to have the lowest prices for pharmaceuticals, medical devices, and physician payments.

• Americans generally receive more medical care than individuals in other countries, which significantly contributes to the higher overall healthcare costs; for example, a person in the U.S. is more likely to undergo open heart surgery after a heart attack than in other countries.
• Medicaid pays less than Medicare for many prescription drugs because Medicaid discounts are legally fixed, whereas Medicare prices are negotiated by private insurers and drug companies.
• Government healthcare plans often reimburse providers at rates below overhead costs, causing healthcare providers to compensate by charging higher prices to privately insured patients.
• The United States is the world's second-largest manufacturer, with an industrial output valued at US$2.4 trillion in 2013.
• The U.S. manufacturing output exceeds the combined output of Germany, France, India, and Brazil.

• Key industries in the U.S. manufacturing sector include financials, information technology, petroleum, steel, automobiles, construction machinery, aerospace, agricultural machinery, telecommunications, chemicals, electronics, food processing, consumer goods, lumber, mining, and armaments.
• The United States leads the world in airplane manufacturing, which constitutes a significant portion of its industrial output.

• Prominent American aerospace companies include Boeing, Cessna (part of Textron), Lockheed Martin (notably its Skunk Works division), and General Dynamics, which collectively produce the majority of the world’s civilian and military aircraft in factories located across the U.S.

• The U.S. manufacturing sector has experienced significant job losses over recent years; in January 2004, manufacturing employment was 14.3 million, down by 3.0 million jobs (17.5%) since July 2000 and approximately 5.2 million since its historical peak in 1979.
• Manufacturing employment in January 2004 was at its lowest level since July 1950.
• The number of steel workers declined sharply from 500,000 in 1980 to 224,000 in 2000.
• U.S. Census Bureau statistics indicated that starting in 2008, the number of business 'deaths' (closures) began to exceed business 'births' (startups), a trend that persisted at least through 2012.
• The United States produces about 18% of the world’s manufacturing output, although this share has declined as other nations have developed competitive manufacturing industries.
• Job losses in manufacturing have occurred despite continual growth in manufacturing volume, attributed to factors such as increased productivity, international trade, and secular economic trends.

• Growth sectors in the U.S. manufacturing economy include telecommunications, pharmaceuticals, aircraft, and heavy machinery, while low-end, low-skill industries like clothing, toys, and simple manufacturing have declined.
• The shift in manufacturing jobs has resulted in a workforce that is more highly skilled and better paid in certain sectors.

• There is ongoing debate in the United States regarding whether the decline in manufacturing jobs is primarily due to the influence of American labor unions, lower foreign wages, or a combination of both factors.
• The U.S. agricultural sector produces a variety of products including wheat, corn, other grains, fruits, vegetables, cotton, beef, pork, poultry, dairy products, forest products, and fish.

• The Interstate Highway System in the United States extends for a total length of 46,876 miles (75,440 kilometers), serving as a critical infrastructure network for transportation across the country.
• The Port of Long Beach is recognized as one of the largest ports in the United States, playing a significant role in maritime trade and logistics.
• The U.S. economy relies heavily on road transport for the movement of both people and goods, underscoring the critical role of road infrastructure in economic activity.
• Personal transportation in the United States is predominantly dominated by automobiles, which utilize an extensive network of four million miles (6.4 million km) of public roads.
• The United States possesses one of the world's longest highway systems, measuring approximately 57,000 miles (91,700 km) in length.
• As the world's second-largest automobile market, the United States exhibits the highest rate of per-capita vehicle ownership globally, with 765 vehicles per 1,000 Americans.
• Approximately 40% of personal vehicles in the United States are classified as vans, SUVs, or light trucks, reflecting consumer preferences and vehicle market composition.
• Mass transit constitutes 9% of all work-related trips in the United States, indicating its role in daily commuter transportation.
• The transportation of goods by rail in the U.S. is extensive, highlighting the importance of rail freight in the national economy.
• Approximately 31 million passengers annually use intercity rail services in the United States, a relatively low figure attributed in part to the country's low population density in many regions.

• Amtrak, the national intercity passenger rail system, experienced a ridership increase of nearly 37% between the years 2000 and 2010, reflecting growing demand for passenger rail travel during that decade.
• There has been a recent increase in the development of light rail systems across the United States, signaling expansion in urban and suburban rail transit options.
• The state of California is undertaking the construction of the nation’s first high-speed rail system, marking a significant advancement in U.S. rail infrastructure and technology.
• The civil airline industry in the United States is entirely privately owned and has been largely deregulated since 1978.
• Most major airports in the United States are publicly owned, contrasting with the private ownership of airlines.
• The three largest airlines in the world by passengers carried are based in the United States.
• American Airlines became the largest airline in the world after its acquisition of U.S. Airways in 2013.
• Of the thirty busiest passenger airports globally, twelve are located in the United States.
• Hartsfield–Jackson Atlanta International Airport is the busiest passenger airport in the world and is situated in the United States.
• As of 2014, the United States holds the world's fourth largest proven natural gas reserves, positioning it among the top countries globally in this resource category.
• The United States is the second-largest consumer of energy in total usage worldwide, reflecting its significant demand for energy resources.
• In terms of energy consumption per capita, the U.S. ranks seventh, following countries including Canada and several others with higher per capita usage.

• In 2005, the U.S. energy consumption was predominantly derived from fossil fuels, with petroleum accounting for 40% of the nation's energy, coal contributing 23%, and natural gas also providing 23%.

• Nuclear power supplied 8.4% of the U.S. energy in 2005, while renewable energy sources contributed 6.8%, primarily from hydroelectric dams, although other renewable sources were included in this figure.
• American dependence on oil imports increased significantly from 24% in 1970 to 65% by the end of 2005, indicating growing reliance on foreign oil supplies over this period.

• The transportation sector is the largest consumer of oil in the United States, accounting for approximately 69% of U.S. oil consumption in 2006, which aligns with global trends where transportation uses 55% of oil worldwide, as documented in the Hirsch report.
• In 2013, the United States imported 2.808 billion barrels of crude oil, a decrease from 3.377 billion barrels imported in 2010, showing a reduction in crude oil imports over this three-year span.

• Despite being the largest importer of fuel, a 2011 report by The Wall Street Journal indicated that the U.S. was on the verge of becoming a net fuel exporter for the first time in 62 years, with expectations that this status would continue until 2020.
• Petroleum became the major export from the United States in 2011, marking a significant shift in the country’s energy trade balance.
• The Internet was originally developed in the United States, establishing the country as a foundational leader in global telecommunications infrastructure.
• The United States hosts many of the world's largest Internet hubs, serving as critical nodes for global data traffic and connectivity.

• The United States is the world's second-largest trading nation, with approximately 60% of funds used in international trade denominated in U.S. dollars, which also serve as the standard currency unit for international commodity markets such as gold and petroleum.
• The North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), established in 1994, created one of the largest trade blocs globally, encompassing the U.S., Canada, and Mexico.

• Since 1976, the U.S. has consistently experienced merchandise trade deficits with other countries, and since 1982, it has maintained current account deficits; however, the U.S. has preserved a long-standing surplus in its trade in services, reaching a record US$231 billion in 2013.

• The U.S. trade deficit increased from $502 billion in 2016 to $552 billion in 2017, marking a $50 billion or 10% rise; in 2017, total imports amounted to $2.90 trillion, exports to $2.35 trillion, with a net goods deficit of $807 billion and a net services surplus of $255 billion.
• The ten largest trading partners of the United States are China, Canada, Mexico, Japan, Germany, South Korea, the United Kingdom, France, India, and Taiwan.

• The U.S. goods trade deficit with China grew from $347 billion in 2016 to $376 billion in 2017, an increase of $30 billion or 8%; in 2017, the U.S. had goods trade deficits of $71 billion with Mexico and $17 billion with Canada.

• According to the KOF index of globalization and the globalization index by A.T. Kearney/Foreign Policy Magazine, the United States exhibits a relatively high degree of globalization; additionally, U.S. workers remit one-third of all global remittances.
• In 2014, the U.S. balance of trade in goods by product category and trading partner showed significant deficits and surpluses as follows:

• Computers: Overall deficit of $155.0 billion, with the largest deficit against China at $151.9 billion; surpluses with Euro area ($3.4 billion), Middle East ($20.9 billion), and Latin America ($12.1 billion).

• Oil, gas, minerals: Total deficit of $149.7 billion, with notable deficits against Canada ($79.8 billion) and Middle East ($45.1 billion); surpluses with Euro area ($6.4 billion) and Japan ($2.4 billion).
• Transportation: Total deficit of $106.3 billion, with large deficits against Japan ($46.2 billion) and Mexico ($59.5 billion); surplus with China ($10.9 billion) and Middle East ($17.1 billion).
• Apparel: Deficit of $69.9 billion, primarily with China ($56.3 billion) and Mexico ($4.2 billion).
• Electrical equipment: Deficit of $40.4 billion, largest with China ($35.9 billion); surpluses with Canada ($10.0 billion) and Middle East ($1.8 billion).
• Miscellaneous manufacturing: Deficit of $25.8 billion, with deficits against China ($35.3 billion) and Mexico ($2.8 billion); surpluses with Euro area ($4.9 billion) and Canada ($5.8 billion).
• Furniture: Deficit of $22.6 billion, mainly with China ($18.3 billion) and Mexico ($1.6 billion).

• Machinery: Deficit of $22.4 billion, with deficits against Euro area ($27.0 billion) and Japan ($18.8 billion); surpluses with Mexico ($3.9 billion), Pacific region ($7.6 billion), Canada ($18.1 billion), Middle East ($4.5 billion), and Latin America ($9.1 billion).

• Primary metals: Deficit of $19.1 billion, with deficits against China ($3.1 billion) and Japan ($1.8 billion); surpluses with Euro area ($3.1 billion), Mexico ($1.0 billion), Pacific ($1.9 billion).

• Fabricated metals: Deficit of $18.5 billion, with deficits against China ($17.9 billion) and Euro area ($5.9 billion); surpluses with Mexico ($2.8 billion), Canada ($7.3 billion), and Latin America ($1.9 billion).
• Plastics: Deficit of $15.0 billion, with deficits against China ($15.7 billion) and Euro area ($1.9 billion); surpluses with Mexico ($5.7 billion) and Canada ($2.6 billion).
• Textile: Deficit of $14.7 billion, with deficits against China ($12.3 billion) and Euro area ($1.1 billion); surpluses with Mexico ($2.8 billion) and Canada ($1.5 billion).
• Beverages and tobacco: Deficit of $10.6 billion, with deficits against Euro area ($9.9 billion) and Mexico ($3.3 billion); small surpluses with China ($1.3 billion) and Canada ($1.0 billion).
• Nonmetallic minerals: Deficit of $8.9 billion, with deficits against China ($6.1 billion) and Euro area ($1.9 billion); surpluses with Canada ($1.9 billion).
• Paper: Deficit of $5.8 billion, with deficits against Canada ($9.8 billion); surpluses with Euro area ($1.2 billion), Japan ($1.1 billion), Mexico ($4.3 billion), and Pacific ($1.2 billion).

• Chemicals: Deficit of $4.7 billion, with a large deficit against Euro area ($39.5 billion); surpluses with Mexico ($19.1 billion), Pacific ($3.2 billion), Canada ($4.6 billion), and Latin America ($15.8 billion).
• Food: Surplus of $9.5 billion, with surpluses against Japan ($6.1 billion), Mexico ($4.9 billion), Pacific ($0.9 billion); deficits with Euro area ($3.6 billion) and Latin America ($1.1 billion).

• Agriculture: Surplus of $29.5 billion, with surpluses against China ($17.8 billion), Euro area ($6.2 billion), Japan ($7.3 billion), Pacific ($5.7 billion), Middle East ($2.8 billion); deficits with Mexico ($3.0 billion) and Latin America ($6.5 billion).
• Petroleum: Surplus of $32.9 billion, with surpluses against Mexico ($16.6 billion), Latin America ($18.3 billion); deficits with Euro area ($1.2 billion) and Canada ($0.1 billion).

• The total U.S. goods trade deficit by country/area in 2014 was as follows: China ($346.1 billion deficit), Euro area ($106.1 billion deficit), Japan ($65.6 billion deficit), Mexico ($54.9 billion deficit), Pacific region ($33.0 billion deficit), Canada ($29.0 billion deficit), Middle East ($15.1 billion deficit), and Latin America ($32.3 billion surplus).
• In 1980, the U.S. public debt stood at $909 billion, representing 33% of the gross domestic product (GDP); by 1990, this debt had more than tripled to $3.2 trillion, equating to 56% of GDP.
• By 2001, the national debt reached $5.7 trillion, but the debt-to-GDP ratio remained consistent with 1990 levels at approximately 56%.
• Debt levels escalated rapidly during the following decade, leading to an increase in the U.S. debt ceiling to $14.3 trillion on January 28, 2010.
• The 2010 United States federal budget projected that total national debt would approach nearly 100% of GDP, up from about 80% in early 2009.
• The White House estimated that the cost of servicing the national debt would surpass $700 billion annually by 2019, a significant rise from $202 billion in 2009.
• In the first quarter of 2018, U.S. household and non-profit net worth exceeded $100 trillion for the first time, having set records continuously since the fourth quarter of 2012.
• As of May 2018, the U.S. federal government or "national debt" was $21.1 trillion, slightly exceeding 100% of GDP.
• The subset of national debt known as "debt held by the public" was approximately 77% of GDP in 2017, ranking the U.S. 43rd highest among nations in that year.
• Debt held by the public increased substantially due to the Great Recession and its aftermath and is projected to continue rising, potentially reaching 100% of GDP by 2028.
• By February 2024, total federal government debt had grown to $34.4 trillion, having increased by about $1 trillion during two separate 100-day periods since the previous June.
• According to U.S. Treasury statistics, at the end of 2006, non-U.S. citizens and institutions owned 44% of the federal debt held by the public.
• As of 2014, China was the largest foreign holder of U.S. public debt, possessing $1.26 trillion in U.S. Treasury bonds.

• The overall financial position of the United States in 2014 included $269.6 trillion in assets owned by households, businesses, and governments within its borders, amounting to more than 15.7 times the annual U.S. GDP.
• During the same period, total debts amounted to $145.8 trillion, approximately 8.5 times the annual U.S. GDP.
• Since 2010, the U.S. Treasury has been able to secure negative real interest rates on government debt, meaning nominal interest rates were lower than the inflation rate.

• Negative real interest rates occur when markets perceive no sufficiently low-risk alternatives or when institutional investors such as insurance companies, pensions, and mutual funds invest heavily in Treasury securities to hedge against risk.
• Economist Lawrence Summers has argued that borrowing at such low rates reduces taxpayer costs and enhances the government's creditworthiness.

• From the late 1940s through the early 1970s, both the U.S. and the U.K. reduced their debt burdens by approximately 30% to 40% of GDP per decade by exploiting periods of negative real interest rates.
• There is no assurance that government debt interest rates will remain at such low levels in the future.

• In January 2012, the U.S. Treasury Borrowing Advisory Committee of the Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association unanimously recommended allowing government debt to be auctioned at even lower, negative absolute interest rates.
• The Federal Reserve serves as the central banking system of the United States, responsible for implementing monetary policy and maintaining financial stability.
• The United States dollar (USD) is the official unit of currency of the United States and is the most widely used currency in international transactions globally.
• Several countries have adopted the U.S. dollar as their official currency, while many other nations use it as a de facto currency for trade and reserves.
