• The federal government employs both monetary policy—such as controlling the money supply through mechanisms like interest rate adjustments—and fiscal policy, including taxation and government spending, to achieve economic objectives of low inflation, high economic growth, and low unemployment.
• The Federal Reserve was established in 1913 as an independent central bank with the primary goals of providing a stable currency and managing the nation’s monetary policy effectively.
• The U.S. dollar is recognized as one of the more stable currencies worldwide, with many countries backing their own currencies by holding U.S. dollar reserves.
• The U.S. dollar continues to hold its position as the world’s primary reserve currency, although this dominance is gradually being challenged by other currencies.

• Approximately two-thirds (around 66%) of global currency reserves are held in U.S. dollars, significantly surpassing the next most popular reserve currency, the euro, which accounts for about 25% of reserves.

• Concerns over the rising U.S. national debt and the implementation of quantitative easing policies have led some analysts to predict a potential decline in the U.S. dollar’s status as the world’s primary reserve currency.
• Despite these predictions, the U.S. dollar has thus far maintained its dominant role in global reserves and international finance.
• At least 72% of Chinese, American, and European respondents to a 2020−2021 European Investment Bank climate survey stated that climate change had an impact on everyday life.

• The Fifth National Climate Assessment reports that climate change affects communities throughout the entire territory of the United States, with impacts varying from state to state and resulting in significant human and economic tolls.
• Scientists now possess relatively high confidence in quantifying the extent to which climate change has influenced specific meteorological events.

• The Fifth National Climate Assessment identifies increased frequency and magnitude of heat waves, droughts, floods, hurricanes, and other extreme weather events as key impacts of climate change in the U.S.

• A 2020 article published in _Science_ predicts that Southern states such as Texas, Florida, and the Deep South will experience more severe economic effects from climate change compared to northern states, some of which may even derive economic benefits.
• The _Science_ article also highlights that the economic impacts of climate change are likely to exacerbate preexisting economic inequalities within the United States.
• In September 2020, a subcommittee of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission issued a report concluding that climate change poses systemic risks to the U.S. financial system.
• The Financial Stability Oversight Council released a report in October 2021 identifying climate change as an emerging and increasing threat to the stability of the U.S. financial system.

• A 2021 survey of 1,422 members of the American Economic Association found that 86 percent of professional economists generally agreed with the statement: "Climate change poses a major risk to the US economy."

• In September 2023, the U.S. Treasury Department, in consultation with the Financial Literacy and Education Commission, issued a report finding that 13% of Americans experienced financial hardship in 2022 due to the effects of climate change following $176 billion in weather-related disasters.

• In April 2024, Consumer Reports announced the release of a report commissioned from ICF International estimating that climate change could cost Americans born in 2024 nearly $500,000 over their lifetimes.
• In 2019, the United States was ranked 23rd on the Transparency International Corruption Perceptions Index.
• The United States received a score of 69 out of 100 on the 2019 Corruption Perceptions Index.
• The 2019 score of 69 represented a decrease from the previous year, as the United States had scored 71 out of 100 in 2018.
• In 2012, the United States ranked 4th in the ease of doing business index, reflecting a favorable environment for business operations.
• The Fraser Institute's 2012 Economic Freedom of the World index placed the United States 18th, indicating a moderate level of economic freedom relative to other nations.

• The Index of Economic Freedom, published by _The Wall Street Journal_ and The Heritage Foundation in 2012, ranked the United States 10th, highlighting its position among the more economically free countries globally.
• In the 2014 Global Enabling Trade Report, the United States was ranked 15th, assessing its ability to facilitate international trade efficiently.
• The Global Competitiveness Report ranked the United States 3rd, underscoring its strong competitive position in the global economy.

• The 2014 Index of Economic Freedom, released by _The Wall Street Journal_ and The Heritage Foundation, indicated that the United States had dropped out of the top ten most economically free countries for the first time, ranking twelfth.
• The United States experienced a steady seven-year decline in economic freedom as measured by the Index of Economic Freedom, a unique trend among countries during that period.

• The Index of Economic Freedom evaluates nations on a scale from 0 to 100 based on their commitment to free enterprise, with lower scores and declining rankings associated with risks such as economic stagnation, high unemployment, and worsening social conditions.
• In 2014, the United States received a score of 75.5 on the Index of Economic Freedom, which was half a point lower than its 2013 score, reflecting a slight deterioration in economic freedom.

• Economist Alan S. Blinder critiques the regulation of the U.S. economy by democratic government, arguing that it is overly short-sighted, focusing on immediate political cycles such as upcoming elections or news cycles rather than long-term benefits.

• Blinder further contends that U.S. economic policy tends to favor initiatives that are politically popular or sound appealing, while avoiding policies that may be economically sound but politically unpopular, regardless of their merit as evaluated by economists.

• The number of countries experiencing banking crises each year since 1800 is documented based on the book _This Time is Different: Eight Centuries of Financial Folly_, which covers seventy countries, showing a general upward trend in crises over time.
• One factor contributing to the increase in banking crises is the gradual rise in the percentage of people receiving wages for their labor.
• A notable feature in the historical data is the near absence of banking crises during the Bretton Woods agreement period, from 1945 to 1971.

• This analysis parallels Figure 10.1 in Reinhart and Rogoff (2009), with additional details available in the "bankingCrises" help file of the Ecdat package from the Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN).
• The U.S. federal government regulates private enterprise through numerous mechanisms, broadly categorized into two types: price control and antitrust regulation.

• One regulatory approach involves direct or indirect price control, exemplified by the creation of state-regulated monopolies such as electric utilities, where prices are set to ensure normal profits.
• Post-Great Depression, the government implemented a complex system to stabilize prices in agricultural markets, which are prone to significant fluctuations due to supply and demand volatility.
• Industries such as trucking and airlines have historically sought government regulation to prevent harmful price-cutting practices, a phenomenon known as regulatory capture.

• Antitrust law represents another form of economic regulation aimed at enhancing market competition by prohibiting anti-competitive practices and mergers that could unduly restrict competition; enforcement involves both government and private parties.

• Bank regulation in the United States is highly fragmented compared to other G10 countries, where typically only one bank regulator exists; in the U.S., regulation occurs at both federal and state levels.

• The U.S. banking regulatory environment is among the most heavily regulated globally, though many regulations focus on privacy, disclosure, fraud prevention, anti-money laundering, anti-terrorism, anti-usury lending, and promoting lending to lower-income segments rather than solely on financial soundness.

• Since the 1970s, government regulation has increasingly targeted social goals such as public health, safety, and environmental protection, with agencies like the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) setting workplace safety standards.
• The United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) establishes and enforces regulations to protect air, water, and land resources.
• The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) regulates drug market approval and mandates disclosure standards for food products.

• American attitudes toward regulation shifted significantly during the last three decades of the 20th century, with policymakers from the 1970s onward increasingly viewing economic regulation as protective of companies at consumers' expense, especially in industries like airlines and trucking.
• Technological advancements introduced new competitors in sectors previously considered natural monopolies, such as telecommunications, prompting legislative efforts to ease regulation.
• During the 1970s, 1980s, and 1990s, leaders of the two dominant U.S. political parties generally supported economic deregulation, though consensus was weaker regarding social regulations.

• Social regulation gained prominence after the Great Depression, World War II, and notably during the 1960s and 1970s, but faced relaxation in the 1980s as the government reduced labor, consumer, and environmental rules to lower business costs and combat inflation.
• Public response to deregulation was mixed, with ongoing concerns about specific issues leading to new regulations in areas such as environmental protection.

• When legislative responses were insufficient, citizens increasingly turned to the courts to address social issues, exemplified by lawsuits against tobacco companies in the 1990s over health risks associated with smoking.
• The 1998 Tobacco Master Settlement Agreement resulted from these lawsuits, providing states with long-term payments to cover medical costs related to smoking-related illnesses.
• Between 2000 and 2008, economic regulation in the United States expanded rapidly, marking the fastest growth since the early 1970s.
• The number of new pages in the Federal Register, a proxy measure for economic regulation, increased from 64,438 pages in 2001 to a record 78,090 pages in 2007.
• Economically significant regulations—defined as those costing more than $100 million annually—increased by 70% during this period.
• Government spending on regulation rose by 62%, from $26.4 billion to $42.7 billion between 2000 and 2008.

• Taxation in the United States is a complex system involving payments to at least four different levels of government, including the federal government, state governments, and various local governments such as counties, municipalities, townships, school districts, and special-purpose districts like fire, utility, and transit districts.
• The forms of taxation in the U.S. encompass taxes on income, property, sales, imports, payroll, estates, and gifts, as well as various fees imposed by different government levels.
• When considering taxation by all government levels combined, the total taxation as a percentage of GDP was approximately 25% (a quarter of GDP) in the year 2011.
• The share of the black market in the U.S. economy is very low compared to other countries, indicating a relatively smaller informal or untaxed economic sector.

• The United States Constitution prohibits a federal wealth tax unless the receipts are distributed to the States based on their populations; however, state and local government property taxes effectively act as a wealth tax on real estate holdings.
• Capital gains taxes in the U.S. are levied on nominal profits rather than inflation-adjusted profits, which effectively results in a wealth tax on the inflation rate embedded in capital gains.
• U.S. taxation is generally progressive, particularly at the federal level, and is considered among the most progressive tax systems in the developed world.
• There is ongoing debate within the U.S. regarding whether the tax system should be made more or less progressive, reflecting differing views on tax equity and economic policy.

• According to the Tax Justice Network in 2022, the United States facilitates more global financial secrecy than Switzerland, the Cayman Islands, and Bermuda combined, highlighting its significant role in international financial opacity.

• The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) provides data on U.S. federal spending and revenue components for the fiscal year 2023, identifying healthcare, Social Security, and defense as the major expenditure categories, with income and payroll taxes serving as the primary revenue sources.

• The CBO baseline scenario comparisons include three key reports: June 2017 (reflecting the deficit trajectory inherited by President Trump from President Obama), April 2018 (incorporating Trump's tax cuts and spending bills), and an April 2018 alternate scenario (assuming the extension of Trump tax cuts and other current policy extensions).
• Public-sector spending in the United States constitutes approximately 38% of GDP, with the federal government accounting for about 21% and state and local governments comprising the remainder.

• Each level of government provides distinct direct services: the federal government is responsible for national defense, research leading to new product development, space exploration, and programs aimed at workforce skill development and job placement, including higher education initiatives.
• Government spending significantly influences local and regional economies as well as the overall pace of economic activity in the United States.
• State governments primarily oversee the construction and maintenance of most highways across the country.
• State, county, and city governments play the leading roles in financing and operating public schools.
• Local governments bear primary responsibility for police and fire protection services.
• In 2016, U.S. state and local governments collectively owed $3 trillion in debt and faced an additional $5 trillion in unfunded liabilities.
• The U.S. welfare system originated in the 1930s during the Great Depression with the enactment of the New Deal legislation.

• The welfare system was expanded in the 1960s under Great Society legislation, which introduced significant programs such as Medicare, Medicaid, the Older Americans Act, and federal education funding.
• In 1998, combined federal, state, and local government spending accounted for nearly 28% of the United States’ gross domestic product.

• During Fiscal Year (FY) 2017, the U.S. federal government spent $3.98 trillion on a budget or cash basis, representing an increase of $128 billion or 3.3% compared to FY2016 spending of $3.85 trillion.
• Major categories of FY2017 federal spending included Healthcare programs such as Medicare and Medicaid, which accounted for $1,077 billion or 27% of total spending.
• Social Security expenditures in FY2017 totaled $939 billion, comprising 24% of the federal budget.
• Non-defense discretionary spending, which funds the operation of federal Departments and Agencies, amounted to $610 billion or 15% of FY2017 spending.
• The Department of Defense received $590 billion in FY2017, also representing 15% of federal expenditures.
• Interest payments on the national debt cost the government $263 billion in FY2017, making up 7% of total spending.
• In FY2017, the federal government collected approximately $3.32 trillion in tax revenue, an increase of $48 billion or 1.5% compared to FY2016.
• The primary sources of federal receipts in FY2017 were individual income taxes totaling $1,587 billion or 48% of total receipts.
• Social Security and Social Insurance taxes contributed $1,162 billion or 35% of total federal revenue in FY2017.
• Corporate taxes generated $297 billion or 9% of the total tax revenue collected in FY2017.
• Additional revenue sources in FY2017 included excise taxes, estate taxes, and gift taxes, though these were smaller components of total receipts.
• Federal revenues in FY2017 represented 17.3% of the gross domestic product (GDP), a slight decrease from 17.7% of GDP in FY2016.
• Over the period from 1980 to 2017, tax revenues averaged approximately 17.4% of GDP.
• The federal budget deficit, defined as expenses exceeding revenues, was $665 billion in FY2017, up $80 billion or 14% from the $585 billion deficit in FY2016.
• The budget deficit in FY2017 equaled 3.5% of GDP, compared to 3.2% of GDP in FY2016.
• The budget deficit was forecasted to increase to $804 billion in FY2018, largely due to the effects of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act and other spending legislation.
• Long-term drivers of federal deficits and debt include demographic trends such as an aging population and healthcare cost inflation.
• Debt held by the public, a key measure of national debt, was approximately $14.7 trillion in 2017, representing 77% of GDP.
• In 2017, U.S. public debt as a percentage of GDP ranked 43rd highest out of 207 countries worldwide.
• The U.S. debt-to-GDP ratio in 2017 was roughly comparable to that of many Western European nations.

• A central characteristic of the U.S. economy is the economic freedom granted to the private sector, which allows it to make the majority of economic decisions regarding the direction and scale of production within the economy.
• This economic freedom is supported by relatively low levels of government regulation and involvement, alongside a judicial system that generally protects property rights and enforces contracts.

• As of the present, the United States hosts 29.6 million small businesses, possesses thirty percent of the world's millionaires, forty percent of the world's billionaires, and is home to 139 of the world's 500 largest companies.
• Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg was notably present at the rollout ceremony of the 787-10 Dreamliner, illustrating the prominence of major U.S. corporations in the global economy.

• Since its inception as an independent nation, the United States has actively encouraged science and innovation, fostering informal cooperation between industry and academia that accelerated research growth in the early 20th century.
• By the late 1930s, the volume of U.S. research had surpassed that of Britain, although the quality of U.S. research at the time was still considered inferior to British and German standards.
• Post-World War II, federal spending on defense research and development (R&D) and antitrust policies significantly contributed to the advancement of U.S. innovation.
• The United States benefits from abundant natural resources, including rich mineral deposits and fertile agricultural soil, complemented by a moderate climate conducive to economic activities.

• The country’s extensive coastlines along the Atlantic Ocean, Pacific Ocean, and the Gulf of Mexico, as well as major inland waterways such as rivers flowing from the interior and the Great Lakes bordering Canada, have historically facilitated shipping and economic integration.
• These extensive waterways have been instrumental in shaping the economic growth of the United States and have helped unify the fifty individual states into a cohesive economic unit.
• The health of the U.S. economy is influenced by the number of workers and, more critically, their productivity levels.
• Consumer spending accounted for approximately 62% of U.S. GDP in 1960, remained stable at that level until about 1981, and subsequently increased to 71% by 2013.
• The United States has experienced steady growth in its labor force throughout its history, a trend that both drives and results from nearly continuous economic expansion.

• Until shortly after World War I, the majority of U.S. workers were immigrants from Europe, their immediate descendants, or African Americans, many of whom were descendants of slaves brought from Africa.

• Beginning in the late 20th century, the United States experienced significant immigration from Latin America, followed by large numbers of Asian immigrants after the removal of nation-origin based immigration quotas.
• The promise of high wages attracted many highly skilled workers from around the world to the United States, alongside millions of illegal immigrants seeking employment in the informal economy.
• More than 13 million people officially entered the United States during the 1990s alone, marking a substantial demographic shift.

• Labor mobility played a crucial role in the American economy’s ability to adapt to changing conditions; for example, when immigrants flooded labor markets on the East Coast, many workers relocated inland to farmland awaiting cultivation.
• Economic opportunities in industrial northern cities attracted black Americans from southern farms during the first half of the 20th century in a movement known as the Great Migration.
• In the United States, the corporation emerged as an association of owners, known as stockholders, who form a business enterprise governed by a complex set of rules and customs.
• Corporations, driven by the process of mass production, such as General Electric, have been instrumental in shaping the economic landscape of the United States.
• In the era of globalization, American investors and corporations exert influence worldwide, extending the reach of the U.S. economy beyond national borders.

• The American government is a major investor in the economy, directing investments toward large-scale public works projects such as the Hoover Dam, military-industrial contracts, and the financial industry.
• The U.S. population is aging, which has significant economic implications for GDP growth, productivity, innovation, inequality, and national debt, as indicated by several studies.
• In 2019, the average age of a worker was 42 years, compared to 38 years in 2000, reflecting an aging workforce.
• By 2030, approximately 59% of adults over 16 years old are projected to be in the labor force, down from 62% in 2015.
• One study estimated that aging since 2000 has reduced productivity by between 0.25% and 0.7% per year.
• GDP growth is influenced by productivity (output per worker) and the number of workers; both declining productivity and a shrinking labor force slow the GDP growth rate.

• Older workers tend to save more, which lowers interest rates; this effect partially offsets the reduction in GDP growth but simultaneously reduces the Federal Reserve's capacity to combat recessions by lowering interest rates.

• Potential strategies to address the economic challenges of an aging population include increasing immigration to bring in younger workers and encouraging higher fertility rates through incentives such as tax breaks, subsidies, and more generous paid leave policies.

• The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) estimated in May 2019 that mandatory spending programs, including Medicare, Medicaid, and Social Security, will continue to grow relative to GDP as the population ages.
• The population aged 65 or older is projected to increase by one-third between 2019 and 2029.
• Mandatory program spending (outlays) accounted for 12.7% of GDP in 2019 and is projected to average 14.4% of GDP during the period from 2025 to 2029.
• The United States has been a global leader in technological innovation since the late 19th century and in scientific research since the mid-20th century.
• In 1876, Alexander Graham Bell was awarded the first U.S. patent for the telephone, marking a significant milestone in American innovation.
• Thomas Edison’s laboratory developed several groundbreaking inventions including the phonograph, the first long-lasting light bulb, and the first viable movie camera.

• Edison’s company pioneered direct current (DC) based electric power delivery and marketed it worldwide, which was later followed by Westinghouse Electric Corporation’s rapid development of alternating current (AC) power delivery systems.
• In the early 20th century, automobile manufacturers Ransom E. Olds and Henry Ford popularized the assembly line, revolutionizing mass production techniques.
• The Wright brothers achieved the first sustained and controlled heavier-than-air powered flight in 1903, a landmark event in aviation history.
• Steve Jobs and Bill Gates are recognized as two of the most prominent American entrepreneurs, symbolizing modern technological entrepreneurship.

• American society places a strong emphasis on entrepreneurship and business, viewing entrepreneurship as the act of undertaking innovations, financing, and business acumen to transform innovations into economic goods.
• Entrepreneurship can lead to the creation of new organizations or revitalization of mature organizations in response to perceived opportunities.
• American entrepreneurs also participate in public service delivery through public-private partnerships, expanding the scope of entrepreneurial activity.
• Traditionally, entrepreneurship refers to starting new businesses or startup companies, but in recent years, the term has expanded to include social and political entrepreneurial activities.

• When entrepreneurial activities occur within existing firms or large organizations, the process is termed intra-preneurship, which may include corporate venturing where large entities spin off new organizations.

• Paul Reynolds, an entrepreneurship scholar and creator of the Global Entrepreneurship Monitor, stated that by retirement age, half of all working men in the U.S. have experienced at least one year of self-employment, and one in four have engaged in self-employment for six or more years.
• Reynolds emphasized that participating in new business creation is a common activity among U.S. workers throughout their careers.
• Scholars such as David Audretsch have documented that business creation is a major driver of economic growth in both the United States and Western Europe.

• The survival rate of U.S. start-ups from 1977 to 2012 has been tracked by the U.S. Census Bureau’s Business Dynamic Statistics and published by Gallup, with data reproduced in the UNESCO Science Report: Towards 2030 (Figure 5.7, p. 143).
• Venture capital as an industry originated in the United States, which continues to dominate the global venture capital market.
• According to the National Venture Capital Association, companies backed by venture capital account for 11% of private sector jobs in the U.S. and generate revenue equivalent to 21% of the U.S. GDP.

• In 2014, total U.S. venture capital investment reached $48.3 billion across 4,356 deals, representing a 61% increase in dollar value and a 4% increase in the number of deals compared to the previous year, as reported by the National Venture Capital Association.
• The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) estimated that by 2014, U.S. venture capital investment had fully recovered to pre-recession levels.

• Venture capital investment in the life sciences sector in 2014 was at its highest level since 2008, with $6.0 billion invested in biotechnology through 470 deals, and $8.6 billion invested overall in life sciences (including biotechnology and medical devices) through 789 deals.

• Within biotechnology investments in 2014, 68% were allocated to first-time or early-stage development deals, 14% to expansion-stage development, 11% to seed-stage companies, and 7% to late-stage companies.
• The software industry led in the number of venture capital deals in 2014, with 1,799 deals totaling $19.8 billion in investment.
• Internet-specific companies ranked second in venture capital investment in 2014, receiving $11.9 billion through 1,005 deals.
• A significant concentration of these venture capital-backed companies is located in California, which accounts for 28% of U.S. research activity.
• Some new American businesses secure funding from angel investors, who are a subset of venture capitalists.
• In 2010, the healthcare/medical sector accounted for the largest share of angel investments at 30% of total angel investments, up from 17% in 2009.

• Other sectors receiving angel investments in 2010 included software (16%, down from 19% in 2007), biotech (15%, up from 8% in 2009), industrial/energy (8%, down from 17% in 2009), retail (5%, down from 8% in 2009), and IT services (5%).
• American consumers are characterized as "venturesome," demonstrating a high willingness to try new products and actively encouraging manufacturers to improve their offerings.
• Since 1985, the United States has experienced three major waves of mergers and acquisitions (M&A), as illustrated in the graph titled "Mergers and Acquisitions in the U.S. since 1985."
• The year 2017 marked the highest level of M&A activity in terms of the number of deals, totaling 12,914 transactions.
• In contrast, the year 2015 recorded the largest overall monetary value of M&A deals in the U.S., amounting to $24 billion.
• The largest merger deal in U.S. history occurred in 2000, when America Online Inc. acquired Time Warner, with the bid exceeding $164 billion.
• Since the year 2000, acquisitions of U.S. companies by Chinese investors have increased significantly by 368%.
• Conversely, acquisitions by U.S. companies of Chinese firms have decreased by 25% since 2000, although there was a brief upward trend in such acquisitions until 2007.
• The United States invests more funds in research and development (R&D) in absolute terms than all other G7 nations combined, with 17.2% more expenditure in 2012.
• Since the year 2000, the gross domestic expenditure on R&D (GERD) in the U.S. has increased by 31.2%.
• Despite this increase, the U.S. has maintained its share of GERD among the G7 nations at approximately 54.0%, compared to 54.2% in 2000.
• The data on gross domestic expenditure on R&D as a percentage of GDP from 2002 to 2013 includes comparisons with other countries, as reported by the UNESCO Science Report: towards 2030.

sections.section_name: Impact of recession on research spending
openai_summarised_points: • U.S. investment in research and development (R&D) generally increased alongside economic growth in the early 2000s, experienced a slight decline during the economic recession, and then rose again as economic growth resumed.
• In 2009, Gross Domestic Expenditure on R&D (GERD) in the United States peaked at US$406 billion, representing 2.82% of the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP).

• Despite the economic recession, GERD remained relatively stable at 2.79% of GDP in 2012 and was projected to decline marginally to 2.73% in 2013 based on provisional data, with expectations to maintain a similar level in 2014.

• In 2012, the federal government was the primary funder of basic research in the U.S., contributing 52.6% of funding, while state governments, universities, and other non-profit organizations collectively provided 26% of basic research funding.
• Funding for experimental development in 2012 was predominantly provided by industry, accounting for 76.4%, compared to 22.1% funded by the federal government.

• According to the UNESCO Science Report: towards 2030 (Figure 1.7), data on world shares of GDP, research spending, researchers, and scientific publications were documented for the years 2009 and 2013.

• Although the United States maintained a high level of investment in R&D, it did not achieve President Barack Obama’s goal of increasing R&D spending to 3% of GDP by the end of his presidency in 2016.
• Between 2009 and 2012, the United States’ share of global research expenditure declined slightly from 30.5% to 28.1%.
• Several countries, including Israel, Japan, and the Republic of Korea, invested more than 4% of their GDP in R&D as of the period discussed.
• Finland and Sweden had plans to increase their GERD-to-GDP ratios to 4% by the year 2020.
• In 2012, business enterprises contributed 59.1% of the United States' Gross Domestic Expenditure on Research and Development (GERD), representing a decline from 69.0% in 2000.
• Private non-profit organizations and foreign entities each accounted for a small fraction of total U.S. R&D spending, contributing 3.3% and 3.8%, respectively.

• The data on the U.S. research and development budget by government agency from 1994 to 2014 is sourced from the UNESCO Science Report: towards 2030, specifically Figure 5.4, which is based on information from the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
• Historically, the United States has been a global leader in business R&D and innovation activities.

• The economic recession of 2008–2009 had a significant and lasting impact on business R&D, particularly affecting small businesses and start-ups, while major R&D performers largely maintained their investment levels.
• According to statistics from the U.S. Census Bureau, starting in 2008, the number of business "deaths" exceeded the number of business "births," a trend that persisted at least through 2012.

• From 2003 to 2008, business research spending in the U.S. generally increased; however, in 2009, R&D expenditure declined by 4% compared to the previous year, followed by a further decrease of 1–2% in 2010.
• Companies operating in high-opportunity sectors such as health care reduced their R&D spending less than those in more mature industries like fossil fuels during the recession period.
• The agriculture production sector experienced the largest cutbacks in R&D spending, with a reduction of 3.5% relative to the average R&D to net sales ratio.
• Conversely, the chemicals and allied products industry and the electronic equipment industry exhibited R&D to net sales ratios that were 3.8% and 4.8% higher than the average, respectively.
• Although R&D spending increased in 2011, it remained below the expenditure levels recorded in 2008.

• By 2012, the growth rate of business-funded R&D had recovered, but future trends depend on factors such as economic recovery and growth, federal research funding levels, and the overall business climate.

sections.section_name: Research spending at the state level
openai_summarised_points: • Research spending in the United States varies significantly across states, with notable disparities in the proportion of GDP devoted to research and development (R&D).

• In 2010, six states—New Mexico, Maryland, Massachusetts, Washington, California, and Michigan—each allocated 3.9% or more of their GDP to R&D, collectively accounting for 42% of the national research expenditure.

• California led in R&D concentration in 2010, accounting for 28.1% of all U.S. R&D spending, followed by Massachusetts (5.7%), New Jersey (5.6%), Washington State (5.5%), Michigan (5.4%), Texas (5.2%), Illinois (4.8%), New York (3.6%), and Pennsylvania (3.5%).
• Seven states—Arkansas, Nevada, Oklahoma, Louisiana, South Dakota, and Wyoming—each devoted less than 0.8% of their GDP to R&D, indicating much lower research intensity.

• The data on science and engineering by state is sourced from the UNESCO Science Report: towards 2030, Figure 5.6, which is based on information from the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
• San Francisco is recognized as one of the world’s largest financial centers, contributing to the region’s economic and research prominence.
• California hosts Silicon Valley, a globally renowned hub for leading information technology corporations and startups, underscoring the state’s dominance in IT innovation.
• California also features dynamic biotechnology clusters located in the San Francisco Bay Area, Los Angeles, and San Diego, making it a national leader in biotech industries.

• Outside California, major biotechnology clusters exist in Boston/Cambridge (Massachusetts), Maryland, suburban Washington, DC, New York, Seattle, Philadelphia, and Chicago, highlighting key regional centers of biotech activity.
• California provides 13.7% of all science and engineering jobs in the United States, the highest share among all states, with 5.7% of its population employed in these fields.

• The high concentration of science and engineering employment in California is attributed to a combination of academic excellence and strong business R&D focus, exemplified by institutions such as Stanford University and the University of California in proximity to Silicon Valley.

• Similarly, Massachusetts’ Route 128 corridor is notable for its concentration of high-tech firms and corporations, as well as prestigious academic institutions including Harvard University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).
• New Mexico’s elevated research intensity is largely due to the presence of the Los Alamos National Laboratory, a major federally funded research facility.
• Maryland’s high research spending is likely influenced by the concentration of federally funded research institutions within the state.
• Washington State’s research prominence is supported by the presence of major high-tech companies such as Microsoft, Amazon, and Boeing.
• Michigan’s research focus is linked to the location of engineering functions for most automobile manufacturers within the state, reflecting its role in the automotive industry.

• The federal government of the United States, along with most of its 50 states, provides tax credits to specific industries and companies to incentivize engagement in research and development (R&D) activities.
• These tax credits are typically renewed by Congress every few years, indicating a temporary and uncertain availability of such financial incentives.

• A 2012 survey conducted by _The Wall Street Journal_ revealed that companies generally do not consider these tax credits when making decisions about investing in R&D, primarily because they cannot depend on the credits being consistently renewed.
• In 2014, four U.S. multinational corporations—Microsoft, Intel, Johnson & Johnson, and Google—were ranked among the Top 50 companies globally in terms of R&D expenditure volume.

• Several U.S. multinational corporations have consistently appeared in the Top 20 global companies by R&D spending for at least ten years; these include Intel, Microsoft, Johnson & Johnson, Pfizer, and IBM.
• Google was included in the global Top 50 companies by R&D expenditure for the first time in 2013.
• R&D intensity is defined as the ratio of R&D expenditure to net sales, serving as a measure of how much companies invest in research relative to their revenue.

• Airbus, although incorporated in the Netherlands, has its principal manufacturing facilities located in France, Germany, Spain, and the United Kingdom, highlighting the multinational nature of its operations.

• The data on global top 50 companies by R&D volume and intensity in 2014 is sourced from the _UNESCO Science Report: towards 2030_ (2015), specifically Table 9.3, which is based on Hernández et al. (2014) _EU R &D Scoreboard: the 2014 EU Industrial R&D Investment Scoreboard_, published by the European Commission in Brussels, Table 2.2.

sections.section_name: Exports of high-tech goods and patents
openai_summarised_points: • Between 2008 and 2013, the United States' share of high-tech exports as a percentage of the world total is documented in the UNESCO Science Report: towards 2030, Figure 5.10, based on data from the Comtrade database.
• Until 2010, the United States was a net exporter of pharmaceuticals; however, since 2011, it has transitioned to being a net importer of pharmaceutical goods.
• The United States is characterized as a post-industrial country where imports of high-tech products significantly exceed exports.

• Despite the trade imbalance in high-tech products, the United States possesses a technologically skilled workforce that generates a substantial volume of patents, enabling continued profit through licensing or the sale of these patents.
• Within the United States' scientific industries engaged in research, 9.1% of products and services are related to the licensing of intellectual property rights.
• In the realm of intellectual property trade, the United States remains unrivalled globally.
• Income from royalties and licensing in the United States reached $129.2 billion in 2013, the highest amount worldwide.
• Japan ranked second in income from royalties and licensing in 2013, with receipts totaling $31.6 billion.
• The United States' payments for the use of intellectual property in 2013 amounted to $39.0 billion.
• Only Ireland exceeded the United States in payments for intellectual property use in 2013, with payments totaling $46.4 billion.
• The Fortune 500 ranks America's largest companies annually by revenue, with the top spot between 2000 and 2022 held by General Motors (GM), ExxonMobil, or Walmart.

• As of February 9, 2023, the largest American companies by market capitalization include Apple, Microsoft, Google (via Alphabet), Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway, Tesla, Nvidia, Visa, ExxonMobil, and Meta Platforms.

• Many of these companies are also among the most valuable global brands, with Coca-Cola, The Walt Disney Company, and McDonald's joining the largest companies by revenue and market cap on Forbes' annual ranking of most valuable brands.
• Certain American industries are dominated by a few major companies, leading to terms like "Big Three" or "Big Four," exemplified by:
• The Big Three credit reporting agencies: Equifax, Experian, and TransUnion.
• The Big Three automobile manufacturers: Ford, General Motors, and Stellantis.
• The Big Four accounting firms: Deloitte, Ernst & Young, KPMG, and PwC.
• The Big Four communications carriers: Verizon, AT&T, T-Mobile/Sprint, and Dish Network.
• The American energy industry is among the largest globally, encompassing oil, natural gas, coal, and renewable energy sectors.
• The largest American energy companies by market capitalization are primarily in oil and gas, including ExxonMobil, Chevron, ConocoPhillips, and Schlumberger.
• British oil companies BP and Shell have a significant presence in the U.S. energy market and are listed on both the London Stock Exchange and New York Stock Exchange.
• Many large American petroleum companies, along with BP, trace their origins to Standard Oil, a former monopoly led by John D. Rockefeller.
• The U.S. coal industry, valued at approximately $30 billion, is dominated by Peabody Energy, the world's largest coal company, which reported nearly $23 billion in revenue in 2021.
• Major coal mining in the United States occurs primarily in Wyoming and Appalachian states such as West Virginia, Pennsylvania, and Kentucky.

• A 2012 Deloitte report in STORES magazine revealed that in fiscal year 2010, 32% of the world's top 250 largest retailers by retail sales revenue were U.S.-based, collectively accounting for 41% of total retail sales revenue among those top retailers.
• The United States is the global leader in semiconductor production; in 2011, half of the world's 20 largest semiconductor manufacturers by sales were American companies.
• The CHIPS and Science Act, passed under President Joe Biden's administration, is a bipartisan bill designed to enhance semiconductor production in the United States.
• Prominent American semiconductor and chip companies include Broadcom, Intel, AMD, and Qualcomm.
• Many of the largest U.S. firms by market capitalization are technology companies, dominated by the "Big Five" tech giants: Apple, Amazon, Google, Microsoft, and Meta.
• The American technology industry also includes major hardware manufacturers such as Dell Technologies, IBM, Hewlett-Packard, and Cisco.
• Leading software and computing infrastructure companies in the U.S. include Oracle, Salesforce, Adobe, and Intuit.
• The U.S. film industry produces nearly all of the world's highest-grossing films.
• Many of the world's best-selling music artists are based in the United States.
• Major American media companies include The Walt Disney Company, Warner Bros. Discovery, Netflix, Comcast, Paramount Global, and Fox.

• The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) is the largest stock exchange globally, measured by the value of its listed companies' securities, being more than three times larger than any other stock exchange worldwide.
• As of October 2008, the combined market capitalization of all domestic companies listed on the NYSE was US$10.1 trillion.
• NASDAQ is another major American stock exchange and ranks as the world's third-largest exchange after the NYSE and Japan's Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE).
• Despite being third in size, NASDAQ's trade value exceeds that of Japan's Tokyo Stock Exchange.
• NASDAQ is recognized as the largest electronic screen-based equity securities trading market in the United States, hosting approximately 3,800 companies and corporations.
• NASDAQ experiences more trading volume per hour than any other stock exchange globally.

• A 2014 study by New York University analyzing the U.S. stock market found that in the short term, stock variations are primarily explained by factors influencing risk tolerance independently of macroeconomic fundamentals.
• In the long term, the U.S. stock market is significantly influenced by shocks that redistribute rewards between workers and shareholders at a given production level.
• Productivity shocks have a minimal role in historical stock market fluctuations across all time horizons in the U.S. market.
• The U.S. finance industry’s share of total non-farm business profits increased dramatically from 10% in 1947 to 50% by 2010.
• Over the same period, finance industry income as a percentage of GDP rose from 2.5% to 7.5%, and its share of all corporate income grew from 10% to 20%.
• The mean earnings per employee hour in the finance sector relative to all other sectors closely parallels the share of total U.S. income earned by the top 1% income earners since 1930.

• The average salary in New York City's finance industry increased from $80,000 in 1981 to $360,000 in 2011, while the average salary for all New York City workers rose from $40,000 to $70,000 during the same period.
• In 1988, the U.S. had approximately 12,500 banks with less than $300 million in deposits and about 900 banks with deposits exceeding that amount.
• By 2012, the number of banks with less than $300 million in deposits had decreased to 4,200, while banks with more than $300 million in deposits increased to over 1,800.

• The top ten U.S. banks by assets are: 1) JP Morgan Chase, 2) Bank of America, 3) Citigroup, 4) Wells Fargo, 5) Goldman Sachs, 6) Morgan Stanley, 7) U.S. Bancorp, 8) Bank of New York Mellon, 9) HSBC North American Holdings, and 10) Capital One Financial.
• A 2012 International Monetary Fund (IMF) study concluded that the U.S. financial sector has grown excessively large and is impeding overall economic growth.
• Economist Thomas Philippon of New York University estimated that the U.S. spends $300 billion annually in excess on financial services and suggested that the finance sector should shrink by 20%.

• Economists from Harvard University and the University of Chicago, in 2014, found that each dollar earned by research and development workers adds $5 to GDP, whereas each dollar paid to finance industry workers reduces GDP by $0.60.
• A study by the Bank for International Settlements similarly concluded that the finance industry hampers economic growth and negatively affects research and development-based industries.

• The Economy of Alabama is characterized by diverse industries including manufacturing, aerospace, finance, and biotechnology, with significant contributions from automotive production and steel manufacturing.
• The Economy of Alaska heavily relies on natural resources such as oil, natural gas, fishing, and tourism, with the petroleum industry being a major economic driver.
• The Economy of Arizona is driven by sectors like technology, manufacturing, mining, and tourism, with a growing emphasis on renewable energy and aerospace industries.
• The Economy of Arkansas includes agriculture, manufacturing, and services, with notable industries in poultry, rice production, and retail, anchored by companies like Walmart.
• The Economy of California is the largest state economy in the U.S., with strengths in technology (Silicon Valley), entertainment (Hollywood), agriculture, manufacturing, and international trade.
• The Economy of Colorado features a mix of industries including aerospace, technology, agriculture, and tourism, supported by a highly educated workforce and natural resources.
• The Economy of Connecticut is known for finance, insurance, manufacturing, and aerospace, with a strong presence of hedge funds and corporate headquarters.
• The Economy of Delaware benefits from a favorable corporate tax environment, with key sectors including finance, chemical manufacturing, and agriculture.
• The Economy of Florida is driven by tourism, agriculture, aerospace, and international trade, with major contributions from the cruise industry and citrus production.
• The Economy of Georgia includes diverse sectors such as agriculture, manufacturing, film production, and logistics, with Atlanta serving as a major transportation hub.
• The Economy of Hawaii is largely dependent on tourism, military defense, agriculture, and services, with a significant role played by the hospitality industry.
• The Economy of Idaho is based on agriculture, manufacturing, technology, and outdoor recreation, with potatoes being a notable agricultural product.
• The Economy of Illinois is diverse, with strengths in manufacturing, agriculture, finance, and technology, anchored by Chicago’s role as a financial and transportation center.
• The Economy of Indiana relies on manufacturing, agriculture, and healthcare, with automotive production and steel manufacturing being significant contributors.
• The Economy of Iowa is predominantly agricultural, with corn, soybeans, and pork production as key components, alongside manufacturing and biotechnology sectors.
• The Economy of Kansas is centered on agriculture, aviation, manufacturing, and energy, with wheat production and aircraft manufacturing as notable industries.
• The Economy of Kentucky includes automotive manufacturing, agriculture, bourbon production, and logistics, with a growing emphasis on aerospace and healthcare.
• The Economy of Louisiana is driven by energy production (oil and gas), petrochemicals, agriculture, and tourism, with the Port of New Orleans playing a critical role in trade.
• The Economy of Maine focuses on agriculture, fishing, forestry, manufacturing, and tourism, with lobster fishing being a significant economic activity.
• The Economy of Maryland benefits from proximity to Washington, D.C., with strong sectors in biotechnology, defense contracting, and information technology.
• The Economy of Massachusetts is characterized by education, healthcare, technology, finance, and biotechnology, with Boston as a major economic and innovation hub.
• The Economy of Michigan is historically rooted in automotive manufacturing, with diversification into technology, healthcare, and agriculture in recent years.
• The Economy of Minnesota includes manufacturing, agriculture, healthcare, and finance, with a strong presence of Fortune 500 companies.
• The Economy of Mississippi relies on agriculture, manufacturing, and services, with significant contributions from poultry, catfish farming, and automotive assembly.
• The Economy of Missouri features manufacturing, agriculture, aerospace, and transportation, with St. Louis and Kansas City as economic centers.
• The Economy of Montana is based on agriculture, mining, tourism, and energy production, with significant natural resources including coal and oil.
• The Economy of Nebraska is largely agricultural, focusing on corn, beef, and pork production, alongside manufacturing and transportation sectors.
• The Economy of Nevada depends heavily on tourism, gaming, and mining, with Las Vegas as a global entertainment and hospitality center.
• The Economy of New Hampshire includes manufacturing, technology, healthcare, and tourism, with a strong emphasis on quality of life and education.
• The Economy of New Jersey is diverse, with pharmaceuticals, finance, manufacturing, and transportation as key sectors, benefiting from proximity to New York City.
• The Economy of New Mexico is driven by energy production, technology, agriculture, and tourism, with significant federal government and military presence.
• The Economy of New York (state) is one of the largest in the U.S., with finance (Wall Street), media, technology, manufacturing, and agriculture as major sectors.
• The Economy of North Carolina is diverse, with finance, technology, manufacturing, and agriculture, supported by research institutions like the Research Triangle Park.
• The Economy of North Dakota is heavily influenced by energy production (oil and gas), agriculture, and manufacturing, with rapid growth due to shale oil development.
• The Economy of Ohio features manufacturing, agriculture, finance, and healthcare, with a strong industrial base and growing technology sector.
• The Economy of Oklahoma is centered on energy production (oil and natural gas), agriculture, manufacturing, and aerospace industries.
• The Economy of Oregon includes technology, agriculture, forestry, and manufacturing, with Portland as a key economic and cultural center.
• The Economy of Pennsylvania is diverse, with manufacturing, agriculture, energy, finance, and healthcare, anchored by cities like Philadelphia and Pittsburgh.
• The Economy of Rhode Island focuses on manufacturing, healthcare, education, and tourism, with a significant maritime industry.
• The Economy of South Carolina includes automotive manufacturing, aerospace, agriculture, and tourism, with growing industrial development.
• The Economy of South Dakota is based on agriculture, finance, manufacturing, and tourism, with a notable presence of banking institutions.
• The Economy of Tennessee features manufacturing, agriculture, healthcare, and tourism, with Nashville as a cultural and economic hub.
• The Economy of Texas is the second-largest state economy in the U.S., driven by energy production, technology, agriculture, manufacturing, and international trade.
• The Economy of Utah includes technology, mining, agriculture, and tourism, with a rapidly growing tech sector known as the Silicon Slopes.
• The Economy of Vermont is characterized by agriculture, manufacturing, tourism, and services, with dairy farming and maple syrup production as key industries.
• The Economy of Virginia benefits from federal government presence, technology, agriculture, and military contracting, with Northern Virginia as a major economic region.
• The Economy of Washington, D.C. is dominated by federal government activities, professional services, tourism, and education sectors.
• The Economy of Washington (state) includes technology, aerospace, agriculture, and trade, with Seattle as a major economic and cultural center.
• The Economy of West Virginia is based on energy production (coal and natural gas), manufacturing, and agriculture, with ongoing economic diversification efforts.
• The Economy of Wisconsin features manufacturing, agriculture, healthcare, and biotechnology, with dairy farming as a prominent agricultural sector.
• The Economy of Wyoming relies on energy production (coal, oil, natural gas), agriculture, and tourism, with significant natural resource extraction.

• The economy of American Samoa is primarily based on tuna fishing and processing, with the tuna canning industry being the largest private employer; the territory benefits from preferential access to U.S. markets under the Tuna Act and receives significant financial assistance from the U.S. government, including annual grants and subsidies.

• Guam's economy relies heavily on tourism, particularly from Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan, with the tourism sector accounting for a substantial portion of the territory's GDP; the U.S. military presence also contributes significantly to the local economy through defense spending and related activities.

• The economy of the Northern Mariana Islands is largely driven by tourism and garment manufacturing, although the garment industry has declined since the early 2000s due to the end of trade preferences; the territory receives federal funding and benefits from its political status as a U.S. commonwealth.

• Puerto Rico's economy is diverse, encompassing manufacturing (notably pharmaceuticals, electronics, and textiles), services, and agriculture; it has faced significant challenges including a prolonged recession, high public debt, and population decline, but benefits from U.S. federal programs and tax incentives designed to promote economic development.

• The economy of the United States Virgin Islands is based on tourism, manufacturing (including rum production), and services; the territory has experienced economic difficulties related to government debt and infrastructure issues, but continues to receive federal support and promotes tourism as a key economic driver.
